story:
On February 24th 2014, the Anti-Homosexuality Act, also known as the "Kill the Gays Bill" was signed by the president of Uganda. On February 27th we highjacked Uganda's flag and silkscreened a limited series of 50 posters to support human rights world wide.We sent the first print to Mister President Museveni. We've yet to hear from him.

The other 49 posters will be sold right here in order to raise awareness around this huge human rights issue. All benefits will go to a Amnesty International Canada, who work with LGBTI organizations on the ground that need direct support. 

Contact for more information, or to get involved: aflagforuganda@gmail.com

All benefits will go to a Amnesty International Canada, who work with LGBTI organizations on the ground that need direct support. Contact for more information, or to get involved: aflagforuganda@gmail.com

story:
How Does It Work

The artist is sent a holographic label to adhere to the back of his/her work of art. The label has security characteristics which include:


Being tamper evident (it cannot be removed without being destroyed, thus preventing the transfer or exchange of labels).

Having visible  alphanumeric information on the label which identifies the work of art with each label.

Having invisible  to the human eye alphanumeric information, different from the visible, on the label which can only be viewed and identified by artprotected.com.


Artistic works will always have proof of originality, both for themselves and their consumers.

It will add value to each work of art and eliminate national or international forgeries and counterfeiting.

Should an artist see his/her work fraudulently displayed online he/she will have a forum to alert the public and artprotected.com will notify the world.

5% of total funds raised will go towards the International Child Art Foundation (ICAF). 

G.M. Nashville, TN "I think it is a great idea and I look forward to having a membership and protecting my art work."

Why You Need artprotected.com

Original art is part of the life and soul of an artist. Having others take credit for your visions and thought is painful enough without them also making a profit from you efforts. The artist original is like a snowflake, unique unto itself, just as the art protected.com holographic label and program.

R.F. Tweksbury, MA "I've always felt uncomfortable about showing my art online thinking others can take it as their own. Great concept."

Tech Talk About The artprotected.com Labels, supplied by:

Microtrace Holographic Labels, Microtrace, LLC, Minn., MN 55440

Microtrace Microtaggant Identification Particles are the original taggant technology and is the origin of the word "taggant". Originally developed by 3M, Microtrace Microtaggant particles are microscopic - ranging in size from 20 microns to 1,200 microns. Each particle is uniquely encoded exclusively for artprotected.com - acting as a virtual fingerprint, resulting in positive, error-free identification every time. Artprotected.com has its own uniquely designed and manufactured 3M particle chemistry supplied to Microtrace for the labels.

Microtrace's Spectral Taggant is a security ink specifically for print applications (label). When developing the Spectral Taggant Microtrace did so from the perspective of a counterfeiter. Microtrace's Spectral Taggant is a proprietary, multi-component chemistry requiring advance manufacturing and systhesis. They are designed and manufactured in house by Microtrace.

Microtrace's proprietary Spectral Reader is a sophisticated hand held device which gathers hundreds of data points per reading to ensure an exact match to the Spectral Taggant signature. Even a small change in substrate or printing technique could lead to a failed reading. This level of accuracy is required to ensure the dectector cannot be fooled by even the most determined counterfeiter.

Artprotected Perks to the Artist

His/her work of art is displayed on the artprotected.com website as being original and not subject to forgery.

The intrinsic value of their work of art goes up because of the added protection of being an original.

There can be a link to the artist website providing greater exposure of their artwork.

The artist and consumer, should they find a forgery online or elsewhere, can immediately contact artprotected.com for free verification services.

The artprotected.com website will have a place for artist and their customers for feedback as to any indications of forgeries or counterfeiting. The site will serve as a notification for the latest updates regarding forgeries. Creators of original works of art will have a site to notify the world of any forgeries of their artworks.

L.H. Trenton, NJ "It will be fun seeing my giclees online and knowing they can't be forged."

How do I join the artprotected.com program/website?

Backers of the Indiegogo campaign will become members as indicated in the list of perks.

After the Indiegogo campaign any new artists are required to join at an annual fee of $ 15.00. They are also required to purchase the artprotected.com labels which will be priced on a sliding scale from a high of $ 5.00 each for a minimum of 5 to as low as $ 2.00 in larger quantities. It should be noted that many artist will choose to have the holographic label in a visible location with their own trademark/logo. For instance, on prints, posters, or photographs. This may require an additional setup fee for production.

Also, membership allows uploads  to the artprotected.com website for all to see or password protected for only the artist and their customers to see.

When will the first run of labels be available? 

Artprotected.com labels will be available almost immediately after the conclusion of the Indiegogo campaign. Label designs are in the final stage of development at this time and production runs are scheduled to coincide with the conclusion of the campaign.

Customized labels for artprotected.com members will require an additional 4-6 weeks from receipt of final draft. Please note that all labels must have the wording artprotected.com  . There will also be additional charges for the printing of customized labels. Lastly, only artprotected.com will have access and knowledge of the embedded (invisible) information on each label.

L.J Fort Collins, CO "I like the protection as well as having a link to my website".

Can the artprotected.com labels be forged?

No.

Each artprotected.com label is unique unto itself and easily tested for authenticity via the invisible information and taggant security method. It is impossible for anyone else or company to reproduce a taggant which contains specific and secure information as to its makeup.

Lastly, artprotected.com will maintain all embedded information offline, thereby making the process impossible to hack.

Can anyone view artprotected.com works of art online?

Yes, if you, the artist chooses. In this way an artist can promote his/her works of art on the site by having them viewable to anyone. Having an artprotected.com. work of art on the site allows for a link to the artist for an additional nominal fee.

Should the artist wish to have his/her works of art on artprotected.com in a confidential manner, he/she may limit the viewing access by having them password protected and accessible only to himself/herself or his/her client/customer.

Will artprotected.com sell membership information to others?

No.

What It Means To The Artist and Lovers of Original Art

Artist’s works will always have proof of originality, both for themselves and for their customers. 

It will add value to each work of art and eliminate national and international forgeries and counterfeiting.

Should an artist see his/her work fraudulently displayed online or elsewhere he/she will have a forum to alert the public and artprotected.com will notify the world.

A special thanks goes out to:

John Pouwels
Wine Cellar Art Gallery 

Philip Barter
Barter Gallery

Benjamin Speed
SummerflyProductions.com

Marty Lyons
studio3graphics

story:
Aloha dear friends!

My name is Sarah Beetson, and I'm a British artist and illustrator who lives mostly in Australia. During my career, I have illustrated for Stella McCartney, The British Fashion Council, The Times and The Telegraph (UK), The Wall Street Journal, Delta Airlines, Ford Germany, Compendium Inc, Reader's Digest, Die Roten Punkte and Amanda Palmer. I have exhibited my work in London, Paris, Portland, New York, Ottawa, Adelaide, Melbourne and The Gold Coast, Australia. Here's some of my work:

My Coney Island Dream...

Next summer, I plan to spend 3 months in Coney Island, USA, in a self-initiated artist residency. I will stay in an artists' loft in Brooklyn, and travel out to Coney every day on the subway, photographing and drawing all that I see and immersing myself in this most inspiring place.

Since I first discovered it in 2002, I have made 5 short 1-day pilgrimages to Coney Island, on the shores of Brooklyn, New York City. Coney is a decaying wonderland of dilapidated amusements and some of the most edible typography one might endeavour to feast their eyes upon. I have kept scrapbooks of photographs from each trip, which I use to inform illustration work and paintings. Yet, each time I return via the Subway to Stilwell Ave, I am heartbroken to find a little bit more of Coney has died since my last trip. 

What I aim to achieve

This sabbatical will allow me to fully immerse myself in Coney Island for months on end; to experience a summer season, and finally see The Mermaid Parade. Due to being granted time off from work, I will be able to create without restraint, and experience being a full-time artist for the first time. I will create a body of work that will reflect Coney Island's present, as well as examining its history; and paint a portrait of an ever-changing environment that will serve as an interesting visual account of a moment in Coney Island's history in the future. I'll continue to develop this body of work upon my return to Australia, creating some large-scale paintings based upon my experience.

What I'll need to get there

The funds raised will contribute towards airfare from Brisbane to New York (approximately £1,475), rent for 3 months (approx. £2,200), insurance (£300) and living costs whilst I am in Brooklyn, as well as any materials I will need. I won't be working (except for making great new Coney Art!) so I'll have no other income coming in during the 3 month residency. Even if I don't reach my full target, any funds I raise will be a valuable contribution and a helping hand in getting me to Coney Island.

I've done it before....

In 2011, I received a grant from The GCC Council to create this amazing quilt (below), with the help of designer Amy Lane. It won one award (Creative Review UK Best In Book for Illustration), and was nominated for another, and has toured London, Paris (twice!), Melbourne, Gold Coast and Ottawa on exhibition.

Also, my previous crowdfunding project was 132% funded. Your kind donations helped me to create 2 new decks of playing cards, which you can now get as a reward for helping me fund this project...!

If you donate, I have some great rewards for you!

**If your reward is intended to be a Christmas gift, I will ship it to you in time for Christmas, so long as you donate by December 6th.

*** ALL worldwide shipping costs are included in the price of the reward!

Here are some of the things you can get as a thank you for your valued support:

Badges and Postcards (I will even send you one form Coney Island if you like!):

Limited Edition 6-colour hand screen printed unisex tshirts:

Unique, hand made, 1-of-a-kind ORIGINAL ART BMI (body mass index) badges:

The VERY LAST 5 of the Pick Me Up 2012 at Somerset House Prints!

BRAND NEW! Shoe Prints in A4 and A3, VERY limited edition and not available until February 2014!


EXCLUSIVE very, VERY limited edition print leggings! ONLY 1 PAIR CURRENTLY AVAILABLE! Here are the fabric repeats for said leggings plus sneakpeak photo...

Clutch bags, totes and luxurious ipad cases!

GIANT, literally enormous, 120cm x 80cm Artist Edition Prints, screenprinted by Straightjacket Press NSW in around 30 colours, neons, glossed & embossed! Signed, stamped and numbered. ONLY 10 AVAILABLE in each edition!

Plus a plethora of other rewards, including custom art, custom hand painted footwear(!) and portraits! The sky is the limit!

If you made it this far and are still reading, you DESERVE a reward!

Thank you so much for your time and attention. If you can't donate to my campaign - no worries! But you can still spread the word and tell your friends via Facebook, Twitter etc, and that would be soooooo AWESOME!

Love, Rainbows, Carousels and Candy Apples,

Sarah xxx

story:
Short Summary

The "I am the greatest project" is comprised of a series of 2 week long art-based workshops held at the Anna Russo-Sieber's Gallery and will serve disadvantaged youth in Benton Harbor. These workshops will educate our youth in various ways.

Through visual fine arts

Teaching our youth about Muhammad Ali and how he overcame adversity.

Developing Creative Writing skills

Character building

Empowering our youth to be engaged within their own community

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding certified art teachers

Art Supplies which includes 3ft. wooden sculptures

Food/supplies for 20 youth for 2 weeks

Photographer/Videographer

Field trips to colleges and art musuems

 

The Impact

This project will impact the youth by teaching them team building skills, art techniques, critical thinking, problem solving, art appreciation, fosters work-ethics,  self-esteem, and empower's them to make a difference in their community by learning more about adversity and stepping outside of themselves to see others in need.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating authentic art supplies pertinent to the workshop

Donate non-perishable healthy snacks/ bottled water

marketing/advertising

story:
Be The Magic Mural Project

 

My Story

I've been making mixed-media collage for more than a decade. A few years ago my art really took off and I began selling it here and there as well as informally teaching how to make mixed-media collage to others. I was an overworked full-time factory worker and as the job became more exhausting, my creative making became less and less. Last year I decided to make the leap of faith and quit my factory job and become a full-time creative. I now make and sell art, teach art at the local community college as well as at Vancouver Art Space, a wonderful creative outlet at our local mall that provides affordable art classes for folks.  I also lead creative retreats and provide one-on-one creative coaching and mixed-media collage instruction. 

 

One of the store front walls of Vancouver Art Space where I teach has been made available for a mural, the first ever of it's kind at the mall. I submitted a design concept based on the kind of art I make and it has been approved. The mall management has had  the wall prepped, but other than that, there is no budget nor compensation for the mural artist. Most artists have declined to pursue this project due to the lack of compensation and I understand and respect that.... however, I see an opportunity. 

 

The Commitment

I have committed to making this mural. Installation begins November 14th. I forecast that it will take 3 full days to complete. 

I'm asking my community to support me in this project for a few reasons : 

  • Supplies are expensive to cover this much square footage
  • Compensation for the artist esteems the value of the work the artist creates
  • It is a unique opportunity to paint a one-of-a-kind mural in a unique public space
  • It is a great investment of funds into a large project by a local full-time creative entrepreneur.

 

The Risks

The biggest risk for me is that I will make a terrible mural in a very public way.  I've never made a mural before, even though I have been making art for so many years.

I've  made the biggest works of my art career just  in the last several weeks and it went well. It felt good to have all that spaciousness to  fill up with creative goodness.

A mural will be the biggest creative challenge to date for me, and I love to be challenged. I like to expand my creative boundaries and discover what else I am capable of accomplishing.

It is a risk worth taking  for the only way to find out is to just go for it, right?!

The other risk is financial. I can put the supplies on my credit card and I can forego making any income for the three days I will set aside to make this mural, but these are not smart business decisions.

I am taking a risk that I may end up having to pay for all of this out of pocket and lose income while I create the mural.

I am taking a risk that my community might not want to support this kind of project.  But I think these are worthwhile risks that have potential for an amazing outcome.

 

A Leap of Faith

I could play it safe and let an opportunity like this pass me by. But just earlier this I journaled  that one of the things I desire to do is  Make a Mural.  I thought maybe a mural project would be in my future in the next couple years, but I was wrong. This opportunity is Here and Now ... I  HAVE TO GO FOR IT!

I am taking a leap of faith that my skills will serve me well as I tackle the 11x10 foot wall with my mixed-media collage design. I am trusting that it will turn out well and inspire patrons of the mall for the next year or two while the mural is in place. 

I am also trusting that my community will step up and demonstrate support by contributing to this campaign, by contributing to the supplies I need as well as agree with me that an artist ought to be compensated for public art. 

 

Be the Magic 

My art almost always features words that are meant to inspire and uplift the viewer. This mural is no different. 

Imagine. Dream. Create.

Be the magic the world needs. 

 

That magic starts here with you and me. Be the magic by contributing whatever amount feels right to you for this mural project. Be a co-creator with me.

I am taking a risk that I may end up having to pay for all of this out of pocket and lose income while I create the mural.
I am taking a risk that my community might not want to support this kind of project.  But I think these are worthwhile risks that have potential for an amazing outcome.
 
A Leap of Faith

I could play it safe and let an opportunity like this pass me by. But just earlier this I journaled  that one of the things I desire to do is  Make a Mural.  I thought maybe a mural project would be in my future in the next couple years, but I was wrong. This opportunity is Here and Now ... I  HAVE TO GO FOR IT!
I am taking a leap of faith that my skills will serve me well as I tackle the 11x10 foot wall with my mixed-media collage design. I am trusting that it will turn out well and inspire patrons of the mall for the next year or two while the mural is in place. 
I am also trusting that my community will step up and demonstrate support by contributing to this campaign, by contributing to the supplies I need as well as agree with me that an artist ought to be compensated for public art. 
 
Be the Magic 
My art almost always features words that are meant to inspire and uplift the viewer. This mural is no different. 
Imagine. Dream. Create.
Be the magic the world needs. 
 
That magic starts here with you and me. Be the magic by contributing whatever amount feels right to you for this mural project. Be a co-creator with me.

WHO IS SHAJARIAN 

  •
story_txt: WHO IS SHAJARIAN

story:
Hello and Welcome to our campaign page!

 

Who we are:

We are a married creative couple who both received our Master of Fine Arts degrees from the University of Kansas, (where we met!), in 2013. Since graduating, we have been teaching, traveling, and making art throughout the United States. Throughout the summer, we travel to art festivals showing our work and demonstrating our process to the public. Our discipline is Traditional Printmaking; we use the process of silkscreen on paper to create a wide variety of imagery by hand.

 

What we are doing:

Our campaign is to raise money for the build-out of a Transit Ford Cargo Van. With the money we raise, we will be able to retro-fit the van into both a cargo vehicle for our art, and a living space. We will be able to take our art on the road! The goal with the van is to be able to reach as many people with our art as possible.

This is an image of the van we will be outfitting:

This is what our current vehicle looks like:

 

With your help, we will be able to reach farther destinations while being fiscally responsible, since we will be able to live out of our vehicle for days or weeks at a time rather than staying at hotels or Airbnbs. We will also be able to prepare and store food in our van as opposed to eating at restaurants for every meal.

 

What WE need:

$2,050

Our total financial goal is $2,050. This money will be used to take a completely stripped down cargo vehicle, insulate it, create walls, shelving, a bed-platform, and storage space for our artwork. This will help us build out the basic necessities to get us self-sufficient and on the road to tour with this new vehicle.

Since we will be a bit tight after purchasing the vehicle, this is where you come in!

 

Financial Breakdown: i.e. how we will use the campaign money to build out the basics!

 

Natural Wool Insulation - $340 

Havelock Wool from Nevada. All-Natural, non-toxic sheep wool insulation that is superior in mold resistance and sound insulation. We will be using this in all of the walls and ceiling of the van. It is also a much better insulation choice for our bodies and the planet!

Reflective Thinsulate Rolls - $95 

US Energy Products creates this insulation that we will be using to insulate between the metal floor and our plywood interior floor, so we don't cook when we have to park in large, asphalt parking lots.

Formaldehyde - Free Plywood - $370 

Columbian Forest Products makes this non-toxic, soybean based glue plywood that will let us sleep easy knowing we aren’t inhaling toxins while we are touring the country. This will be the main material we will be using to cover the insulated floors, ceilings and walls.

Lumber - $160 

We will need various pieces of dimensional lumber to construct benches and cargo spaces within vehicle. It will be mostly pine for this understructure.

Hardware - $100 

This includes hinges, screws, bolts and anything else that we will be using while constructing our cargo area-basically the stuff that holds it all together.

Insect Screen for Back Doors - $470 

This product is made by Van Upgrades and will be really useful when we need to get fresh air into our vehicle while we are eating or relaxing for the night before the various art events.

Camco Standard Portable Travel Toilet 5.3 Gallon - $75 

When you have to go you have to go. This little guy will sit in a very tasteful bench in our cargo area just in case we have to go to the bathroom at night or on the road, and we don’t have any other options.

Advanced Elements 5 Gallon Solar Shower Bag - $30 

We will use the power of the sun, water and some soap. ‘Nuff said.

High-Efficiency Food Cooler - $310 

This will allow us to keep and prepare food in our van while we are at art events and on the road. This means we will have healthier, better quality, AND cheaper meals; yay!

Fees, packaging, and all that Jazz - $100

This will help to offset costs of packaging and shipping of perks, as well as Indiegogo platform fees, and credit-card fees.

 

Perks:

What YOU get!

If you donate:

 

Any amount

Shout-out on Facebook and Instagram to let all your friends know how awesome you are. unlimited

 

$10

Everyone who gives at least $10 will receive a personal, handwritten thank you card with a killer sticker, (of our Big Dipper constellation, Golden Snitch, or Iotaphora admirabilis moth), to stick on your water bottle. unlimited

 

$16

Justice Pin Pack (6 handprinted buttons)-that contains one of each of the following pins: Love is love (equal sign in heart), Refugees Welcome (refugee made flag), Safety Pins for Solidarity (safety pin), Islam is Peace ( Arabic calligraphy of "Islam" as dove), "Water is Life", and "Protect our Parks".  unlimited

 

$20 

Your choice Butterfly / Moth / Insect- 5" x 7" - Limited Edition - 40 available

 

$28

Zodiac Constellation of your choice (Glows in the Dark!) 8"x 10" - Limited Edition - 40 available

 

$70

3 - Butterfly / Moth / Insect Prints of your choice-  5" x 7" + Justice Pin Pack - 15 available

 

$100 

Framed  "Mother Moon" (Glows in the Dark!) - 8" x 20" Museum quality white metal frame with non-glare plexiglas, Limited Edition - 8 available

 

$100 

Framed "Perseverance & Skill" (the Golden Snitch from Harry Potter!) - 12"x 16" Museum quality white metal frame with non-glare plexiglas, Limited Edition - 8 available

 

$100 

Framed "Iotaphora admirabilis" (a lovely moth from the Asian continent) - 12"x 16" Museum quality white metal frame with non-glare plexiglas,-Limited Edition - 8 available

 

$300

Commission a 16"x 20" image of your favorite place or animal. (Or, if you would prefer a smaller size, we can do that too!) It could be your family vacation spot, your fur-baby, or a unicorn... (or anything, those are just our personal favorites.) The sky is the limit! You will receive up to 6 signed, numbered images out of an edition of 100. 3 available

 

$1000

We will drive our newly retro-fitted van to YOU in your city, cook you up a fancy grill-out dinner (your choice omnivore, herbivore, fruiti-vore, or whatever!), and host a movie night in our van. Also present will be a bubble machine. Really. I mean, you gave us 1000 bucks, how could we NOT give you bubbles?  1 available

 

What If we Don't make our Goal?

 

If we don't make our entire goal we will have to prioritize what we get done on our van. The most important elements will be to insulate and build the bed platform, so we will focus the funding on these aspects. Some of the other items aren't a complete necessity, but would make traveling much, much easier.

You will still receive your awesome perks, and we will still be able to have this incredible experience, but things will be a lot tighter.

We really do believe that this campaign is totally achievable. With your help we can make this dream a reality!

 

Impact & Mission Statement

Yes, but why should I contribute?

 

Here are 5 good reasons to donate to this campaign:

1. You get a chance to support artists so they can CONTINUE TO CREATE and travel the country sharing their journey with you through social media and newsletters; every dollar that gets donated is a dollar we don’t have to spend time worrying about, and instead we can focus on making the van comfortable so we can make and sell incredible work.

2. You get to tell all your friends that you are an arts supporting philanthropist (High-fives all around!)

3. You will get cool stuff! (Who doesn’t love that?)

4. Your name will be posted on the internets as a supporter of the campaign and the arts.

5. You will have our undying gratitude!

This campaign's success will push us towards a dream we have had ever since starting Midnight Oil Studio & Workshop 3 years ago: travel the country together while sharing our artwork and process with as many people as possible.

   Our Core Beliefs

  • Art and expression has the ability to bring and spread joy and compassion.
  • Traveling fundamentally changes how we understand and interact with the world.
  • Creating and learning how things are made, (understanding process), brings fulfillment.

Helping us reach our goal will give us the ability to travel and share our passion for traditional printmaking, as well as the natural world around us. Connecting with people and sharing our love of the natural world is something we have come to love about our careers as traveling artists.

 

Risks & Challenges:

    itty-bitty living space!

The cargo vehicle, once retrofitted, will be full to the brink, so every cubic inch counts!

Challenges for this project include careful planning and construction of the interior van space and making it all work as smoothly and efficiently as possible. Thankfully, Jonathan has a carpentry background, and Allison is very talented at planning out projects step-by-step so no details are overlooked. With these skills and aptitudes, we know, that with your help, we will be able to build-out our van in a way that allows us to be very comfortable and successful when we are on the road.

There may be challenges, 

but this project is worth the risk.

We are confident in our abilities as artists and know that we have an excellent support base of friends, family, and followers!

So lend a hand:

Pledge any amount you can.
Together let’s make this thing happen!

 

Timeline Plan:

Here is a sneak peek of our timeline so you know what we are up to! Follow along with the buildout process on instagram: @midnightoilstudio

January - March, 2019- In-depth vehicle and material research, vehicle purchase. 

February 1-March 12, 2019- Launch and complete Indiegogo campaign; we are open for donations!

February 15- March 17, 2019- Order and purchase all building materials.

March 1-17, 2019- Basic Build out at Metzger family farm!

 

Basic Buildout Timeline:

 

March 1-4, 2019- Step 1: INSULATE! (against heat, cold, moisture, and sound)

Installing furring strips, natural sheep wool insulation, formaldehyde-free plywood, and                    reflective Thinsulate insulation.       

March 5-9, 2019- Step 2: BUILD THE SKIN!

Building and installing clapboard-like walls, floor, shelving, and bed platform.

March 10-12, 2019- Step 3: PROTECTION & SAFETY!

Painting and re-installing metal bulkhead that came with the van, and installing back door insect netting.

March 13-16, 2019-Step 4: NECESSITIES!

Installing cook stove, solar shower, and fancy-pancy RV porta-potty.

March 17, 2019- Step 5: LET THERE BE LIGHT!

Installing LED tap lights and cleaning up our new home-away-from-home!

March 18-25, 2019- Package and send out perks so YOU can receive them by April 2019.

April 2019- Perks received by YOU!

Fo'evermore- We enjoy our beautiful, retro-fitted van, you enjoy your lovely perks AND that warm, fuzzy feeling that you got to help us make our dreams come true! (Not too shabby!)

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you find yourself digging into your wallet only to discover it is woefully empty, never fear! You can still help us in a number of ways:

1. In-kind donations: if you have no cash, but you do have (for example), a large amount of pine boards that you are hoping to get out of your garage, we would be happy to take them off your hands! Or it could be a box of construction screws! Or whatever, just let us know what you have and we’ll tell you if we could use it!

2. Make some noise, ya’ll! You know people that we don’t! Tell them all about this campaign and what an exciting thing it is we are doing!

3. Use the Indiegogo share tools to post about us all over the internets and social media so more folks can find out about us and help us out!

Please consider a cash match or in-kind donation to make this dream a reality.

 

Please see Indiegogo's rules here.

And that's all, folks! Please let us know if you have any other questions or comments.

Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQ

And that's all there is to it.

.

.

.

.

.

.

.

story:
Karelibaug in Baroda, Gujarat and is also an example of a traditional India being encroached upon by modern, internationalist pressure. The Grünewald source work for the project's left has has no cultural relevance. Yet its technical cogence may have one. To connect that chaotic modern reality with Grünewald's great painting in a larger work is to partake of that synthetic power ..

 

... In that way a bridge between old & new is created- both between the adjoined rectangles of the completed project painting's shape & between new and old Indian realities. To realize this on the ground familiarity is involved; first an examination of the Grünewald in the tiny farm hamlet of Stüppach, Germany and then in Baroda (a.k.a. Vadodara), India within which the work will also be accomplished.

Who We Are

and

 

In a German Hamlet

     Grünewald's 'Madonna of the Garden, with its life size main figures and cosmically lit rural landscape is located amidst the similar village surroundings of Stüppach, Germany in its small parish church there. This is the work to be re-done, in oil painted replica mirror reversed, that will comprise the project's integrated left half. An onsite visit to do this is required. Not simply to copy but to understand its strategies well enough to make the fusion of the worlds as flexible and alive in the final work as the fusion between the divine and mundane are in the Madonna and Child painting alone.

                                                                         

                                        In Modern India

   

    Baroda, Gujarat was where nine months of 2015/16 was spent completing the previous Indiegogo funded project mentioned above. During that time I gained acquaintance both with the place and with its great people. It's also there that have access to space around 5km from the area to be fused with the radiant landscape of the Grünewald. So that while working there I can be close to the work's 'midst'. I learnt a great deal last time. This time I hope to be able, in sharing this work (and its creation) with Baroda's art community as it proceeds, to give back. 

 

Budget

Airfare     ................................................................................    1853.

NYC/Hamburg/Vadodara(Baroda)

 

Germany    .............................................................................     564.

Transit, Accommodation

 

India    .....................................................................................    2933.

Workspace, Materials, Presentation

 

References

    "I contributed to Alex's first 2015 campaign on Indiegogo. It was fascinating, and surprising, how he completed that. If you're in a position to support his work to whatever extent, I urge you to do so. I am convinced the world will be a richer place as a result."

                                                                        Michael Szpakowski 

    "I first saw Alex on the street here- he was living in an ordinary flat in Fatehgunj. I met him when I went with my friend to see his work in progress. His language is not European or Indian- somehow i saw it as having to do with destruction and abstraction. A lot of people got inspired by the installation of what he was working on at MSU's Fine Arts Hall here. I request people to understand how intense he is in this place. It can only be felt by looking at his work.

                                                                        Anuradha Upadhyaya  ('Anuradha')

 

     "Alex took great pains to tend to every detail of the video above. I saw the careful hanging of his painting on a thick broken storefront window. I glanced precise moments ... a cold grey sky, echoes of existential choices, sublimely conceding victory to the rising sun, and the larger picture that consumes this pure artist."

                                                                              James Gallagher

 

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Karelibaug in Baroda, Gujarat and is also an example of a traditional India being encroached upon by modern, internationalist pressure. The Grünewald source work for the project's left has has no cultural relevance. Yet its technical cogence may have one. To connect that chaotic modern reality with Grünewald's great painting in a larger work is to partake of that synthetic power ..

  
... In that way a bridge between old & new is created- both between the adjoined rectangles of the completed project painting's shape & between new and old Indian realities. To realize this on the ground familiarity is involved; first an examination of the Grünewald in the tiny farm hamlet of Stüppach, Germany and then in Baroda (a.k.a. Vadodara), India within which the work will also be accomplished.
Who We Are


and


 
In a German Hamlet

     Grünewald's 'Madonna of the Garden, with its life size main figures and cosmically lit rural landscape is located amidst the similar village surroundings of Stüppach, Germany in its small parish church there. This is the work to be re-done, in oil painted replica mirror reversed, that will comprise the project's integrated left half. An onsite visit to do this is required. Not simply to copy but to understand its strategies well enough to make the fusion of the worlds as flexible and alive in the final work as the fusion between the divine and mundane are in the Madonna and Child painting alone.
                                                                         
                                        In Modern India
   

    Baroda, Gujarat was where nine months of 2015/16 was spent completing the previous Indiegogo funded project mentioned above. During that time I gained acquaintance both with the place and with its great people. It's also there that have access to space around 5km from the area to be fused with the radiant landscape of the Grünewald. So that while working there I can be close to the work's 'midst'. I learnt a great deal last time. This time I hope to be able, in sharing this work (and its creation) with Baroda's art community as it proceeds, to give back. 
 
Budget
Airfare     ................................................................................    1853.
NYC/Hamburg/Vadodara(Baroda)
 
Germany    .............................................................................     564.
Transit, Accommodation
 
India    .....................................................................................    2933.
Workspace, Materials, Presentation
 
References
    "I contributed to Alex's first 2015 campaign on Indiegogo. It was fascinating, and surprising, how he completed that. If you're in a position to support his work to whatever extent, I urge you to do so. I am convinced the world will be a richer place as a result."
                                                                        Michael Szpakowski 
    "I first saw Alex on the street here- he was living in an ordinary flat in Fatehgunj. I met him when I went with my friend to see his work in progress. His language is not European or Indian- somehow i saw it as having to do with destruction and abstraction. A lot of people got inspired by the installation of what he was working on at MSU's Fine Arts Hall here. I request people to understand how intense he is in this place. It can only be felt by looking at his work.
                                                                        Anuradha Upadhyaya  ('Anuradha')
 
     "Alex took great pains to tend to every detail of the video above. I saw the careful hanging of his painting on a thick broken storefront window. I glanced precise moments ... a cold grey sky, echoes of existential choices, sublimely conceding victory to the rising sun, and the larger picture that consumes this pure artist."
                                                                              James Gallagher
 
Short Summary
Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

Introduce yourself and your background.
Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get
Break it down for folks in more detail:

Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.


The Impact
Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
Make it real for people and build trust.


Risks & Challenges
People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
Describe your plan for solving these challenges.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
HISTORY

Hi. My name is Marty Pottenger. Seven years ago I moved from NYC to Portland Maine to see if art could change a city. I’ve been an activist and theater artist since high school. For decades, I resisted identifying as an artist but after years of traditional activism mixed with community-engaged performance projects, I finally had to face the fact that something happens in live theater/performance that doesn’t happen anywhere else. A place gets created where people can realize/connect/remember/decide things about themselves, the world and each other…the sorts of things that end up changing lives.

The idea that’s become “Art At Work” came to me while I was thinking about the scale of challenges we are facing in the world and how innovative, sustainable solutions would very likely be local. The idea was to put creativity to work improving a city’s municipal government by tackling non-arts community problems by designing and implementing arts projects. The basic goal was that art could help cities save money, deepen residents awareness and expectations of local government, and increase the sort of pride among neighborhoods and residents that leads to robust civic engagement.

IMPACT

Since 2007, police officers have turned around historic low morale by partnering with local poets and writing over 100 poems about their work. Public Service construction workers have become more welcoming by sharing stories about their own heritages and carving prints that hang in their workplaces. Officers and poets came together twice for community-wide civic dialogues about the role of the police in Portland, dialogues that began with a poetry readings. The workers who take your money at the parking garage, City Hall treasury, and library desk have written stories, essays, and poems about themselves and their work which were turned into posters that hang next to the elevators, counters and hallways where they work. It’s not been very easy, but it has been hugely rewarding.

Two years ago, the police found themselves in over 15 rock & bottle-throwing confrontations with teenagers angry about the shooting death of an armed man by police officers. The police chief called to ask if I would write and direct a play with officers to perform for high school students. So I asked him to make sure that I bot to work with the department’s toughest officers. After multiple ride-alongs, interviews, workshops and rehearsals, the performance – Radio Calls – was performed by five officers at all 3 Portland high schools. It had a transformative impact on the relationship between the officers and the students, particularly immigrant and refugee students, who are a significant part of our community.

OUR STORY and VIDEOS

You can see excerpts from “Radio Calls” below along with several other videos from different projects. The Public Services Construction Crew talking for the first time ever to the public about the effect of being stereotyped as a ‘shovel leaner’ and the pride they take in the work they do, as artist Katarina Weslien connects street repair and Jackson Pollock. Or (then) lieutenant, who is now our Police Chief, reading his poem and talking about the impact of Art At Work from his perspective. And finally, internationally-respected graffiti artist Tim Clorius, a part of “Good Fences for Good Neighbors” which helped bring our city’s Somali mosque and the East Bayside Neighborhood Organization together.





What We Need & What You Get

We’re asking for your help – money, outreach, encouragement, ideas – in reaching our goal of raising $19,575 before the end of the year if possible. The money will help us continue to pay the artists we work with.. Whatever the amount your contribution will not only let us keep this experiment going in Portland but also help spread what we’ve learned to other cities, artists, and communities. We now have an Art At Work Holyoke. We hear from London UK, Austin TX, & Danbury VT that AAW ideas are making a difference. Some of the 2014 projects that we've been developing with city staff, grassroots leaders, and elected officials --- “All The Way Home” a story exchange with veterans in Cumberland County; “Hearts, Minds & Homes” a 2 year performance project on gentrification and homelessness (two of our most critical issues); and our first Art At Work Lab, a summer learning exchange for artists, municipal staff and organizers from around the country. And there are always projects created in response to real time events and challenges, sort of a “a true reality show” as coined by our newspaper The Portland Press Herald.

We wanted the perks to offer a meaningful connection and to reflect the nature of the work we do. They include original Police Poetry Calendar with poetry and photographs by Portland officers, poets and photographers; an 84 page book about Art At Work; a studio visit with one of our artists; an Art At Work mug; local artist original neighborhood map posters; and a gathering where we will get to meet each other and thank you personally. 

Portland Police Poetry Calendar

Our AAW mug and booklet

Neighborhood map posters by Kyle Bryant, Elizabeth Jabar, Alison Goodwin, and Patrick Corrigan


We’re real good at making a little go far. We’ve been nominated for a National League of Cities ‘Best Practices’; selected as a model of creative placemaking by the National Endowment for the Arts and received a ‘Hero Award’ from our police department for being courageous-enough to propose poetry writing to police officers. We’ve tackled some tough issues, gotten into a couple good scrapes, built relationships with humor and respect, created beautiful public art, inspired conversations, collaborations, and reflection. And we’ve saved the city money. Our team of city workers, community leaders and artists asks for your help to put creativity to work building sustainable relationships and putting ideas into action for more and more cities in the next several years.


Here’s a list of some of the remarkable artists we’ve had the honor to work with. Each of them has offered to host a studio visit for our $1000 contributors, website links below.

Martin Steingesser, poet  http://www.martinsteingesser.com/

Patrick Corrigan, visual artist  http://thirtysevena.com/tagged/Patrick-Corrigan

Gibson Faye-LeBlanc, poet  http://gibsonfayleblanc.com/

Betsy Sholl, poet  http://www.betsysholl.com/

Marty Pottenger, multidisciplinary, theater http://www.martypottenger.com

Dave Wade, photographer  http://www.davewadephoto.com/

Jan Piribeck, visual artist  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WqAcDaNxCzY

Tim Clorius, visual artist http://timclorius.com/

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you are able to contribute money or not, we can use your help. You can use Indiegogo’s Social Media tools, Facebook, Twitter, email, telephone or personal visit to get the word out. We are a community where people, ideas, listening and creativity are at the center. That’s the heart of what we do.

PS - What We Think We Know

Here’s our list of 5 things that happen when people make art. The process of making art dramatically increases people’s ability to 1) tap into a flexible intelligence, 2) function as a team, 3) envision a positive outcome, 4) remember their connections and 5) be willing to take inspired risks that lead to innovative solutions.

story:
I invite you to participate in an artwork that merges ethics with aesthetics, a project that fuses together cultural creation with civic action, painting with philanthropy.

This June in Hammond Louisiana, I will be working with a group of students at Southeast Louisiana State University to build a colossal installation of painted and printed lumber, a towering, three-dimensional mural that will be exhibited in the University gallery there. After the exhibition we will disassemble the structure and then give the painted and printed lumber to The Ginger Ford Northshore Fuller Center for Housing (A Habitat for Humanity affiliate) where they will use the lumber in the construction of a new home for a struggling family.

While many artworks incite contemplation of their subject matter, often causing a rethinking of social problems of our time, this artwork will go one step further and tangibly serve to help the community by becoming the raw materials for the construction of a home.

I need the help of patrons/donors who want to simultaneously support the arts and give a struggling Louisiana family a boost by donating lumber for this project. I hope to utilize four thousand dollars worth of lumber in this project (about the total dimensional lumber used in the construction of a two bedroom home) and hope that you or your company or someone you know might be interested in contributing a portion of that total.

In order to make this a reality, to have a profound impact, to reach a kind of critical mass that I believe can be inspirational, I am asking for donations of all sizes. Of the $4,000 that I hope to gather, 100% of your donation will go to one concrete element of this project, the lumber. For every $20 that you give, I will purchase seven two-by-four studs or three twelve foot long two-by-six joists. Donations of lumber would work as well as financial gifts. The gallery at Southeast Louisiana State University is providing some funding for materials (screws, paint, metal joining hardware, etc.). While my goal is to generate $4000 worth of lumber, if that goal is not met completely, even a partially met goal will result in a powerful artwork and an important gift to Habitat for Humanity.  

In the past year I have carried out two previous, smaller-scaled projects that involved partnerships with Habitat for Humanity (one in Memphis and one in Lexington, KY). This is the first time that I have crowd-sourced the funding for materials and I am excited to open the project to a wider body of participants. It is also my hope that this project will generate a sufficient quantity of painted, printed lumber to completely transform the look of the framed home to be something that will be awe inspiring. A significant motivation of this project is to bring excitement and energy to the organizations that are carrying out this important work across the country (and the world).

If you are interested and want to help in a way that is not financial, I will be seeking volunteers to help to paint and to construct the artwork (both in Memphis in the month of May and in Hammond in June). Feel free to contact me if you are interested in participating in any way. If you can't financially back this project but find it exciting and want to help out, please share this with your friends!

Thank you for all that you do to support the arts!

Cedar Lorca Nordbye

story:
Experience the what the Nashville Scene calls the "Best Literal Art Crawl"

  • Artists create cubes (pods) of their own artwork that the guests can crawl through
  • Varied performances throughout the time of the event 
  • Walk around the perimeter and interact with people inside
  • See loads of art in one place!
  • Help keep the event free for all with your contribution!

Featuring Artists From Multiple Disciplines

Tori Felton
Jenn Deafenbaugh with MAKE NASHVILLE
The Dead Springs
Rebecca Stone and Keech Rainwater
Rebekah Alexander
Abby Coppage
Kyle Numann
Sara Lederach
Travis Weaver and Brandon Greer
Dustin Hedrick
Daisy Dukes
drone room
Gardening, Not Architecture
Tony Youngblood
RabbitxRabbit
M Kelley
Alexandra Sutton
Ashley Lawless of Blue Stocking
Janelle Balfour-Mikes
Eva Young
Marlos E'van
Bridget Bailey
Devon Eloise and Adam Koichi

Where Your Money Goes

Your donation will first go toward the cost of keeping the venue open the week prior and nights of the exhibition. Queen Ave has graciously blocked out this time from other events so we can build out the event. We're opening the doors the previous weekend to help everyone install their creations, rig up lighting and projection, and get a feel for the space. Throughout the rest of the week our participants will tweak and modify their creations until the time of the show.

Just like any event, after venue costs are subtracted the rest will be distributed to the participants. Many costs can arise buying materials for pod construction and performance items; this is simply doing the best we can to reduce burden for everyone involved. How much goes back to them is determined by how much is raised.

Although I am running the event with Tyler Walker, I will take no personal share of any funds raised. I want the artists to benefit first, as they deserve compensation for their work! We need to support our local artists as much as we can, in whatever capacity.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can't contribute right now, but...

  • We're gonna have a donation jar at the event in addition to this fundraiser
  • Please share this far and wide!

Thank you everyone! I'll see you at the event!

story:
HELLO EVERYONE

My name is Stacey. I am a full time artist who has dreamed of designing my very own enamel pin collection.

I started @oldstoriesph on Instagram as a way for me to share my art and designs to the world.

Starting this campaign is a big step closer to making my work as an artist into a brand that creates fun, collectible and wearable art through the help and support of people in this community.

Initial facts:

1. This is a FIXED funding campaign.

- No funds will be collected from backers if the minimum goal of $600 is NOT reached.

2. SURVEYS will be sent to all backers via e-mail when the campaign ends.

-This is very important that you remember to check if you have backed this project. This is where you will choose which designs you are ordering.

3. Please make sure to double-check your shipping information.

- To make sure that your pins arrive safely to the correct addresses. Thank you!

 

THE PINS

***3 designs are available from the start of the campaign. The Pegasus, Griffin, and Centaur.***

The other designs will unlock as goals are met.

All pins are hard enamel, 4-6 colors, gold plating, approximately 2" or less big and have 2 rubber backs to hold the pin secure. Backing card designs are also shown and will be wrapped in self adhesive clear plastic bags and extra bubble wrap.

 

FUNDS and REWARDS

To have enamel pins produced is a lengthy and costly process and can only be made using the funds from this campaign if the minimum goal is met. I will be shipping and managing everything from the Philippines, but I will be having them made outside of the country by a manufacturer that I trust with producing only high quality pins.

These funds go completely to:

- 85% Manufacturing and shipping.

- 10% Backing cards and packaging materials.

- 5% Indiegogo Fees.

(Image above- free individual stickers that come with any pin pledge. Get the sticker that corresponds to the design/s that you chose)

I have also prepared rewards for all backers who help me with this project. Please read each perk carefully to see which available rewards you prefer.

- Free individual sticker of your pin(s) of choice for all backers from the beginning.

- Early bird discounts.

- Reach $1200 in the campaign and everyone gets an exclusive postcard print of a painting I made just for this campaign.

- Additional designs and rewards will be available when a certain amount is raised.

 

(close-ups of the exclusive print and sticker sheet) - more freebie sticker designs available when stretch goals are met)

All products- including sticker sheets and prints, all contribute to the over-all funding to manufacture the pins. So if pins are not your thing, you may still support this project by purchasing other available merch. I want as much to be available to make this into a reality.

 

Production and Shipping Timeline:

Once the funding campaign has ended, production can begin.It takes about a month of production. I will try my best to have them made earlier if I feel comfortable with how the campaign is going.

After packing all orders I'll be shipping them via our local post office in the Philippines. All mail is registered and can ship anywhere internationally. This usually takes 2-4 weeks with a tracking number. (Not accounting for possible delays/holiday traffic)

If everything goes smoothly, your package will arrive by December, 2018. You may always contact me for any inquiries regarding your package.

 

Risks & Challenges

***Please note that this timeline is only if no manufacturing and/or shipping delays occur. I have no control over the manufacturing side (and if there are defects I may have them remade because I wont send defective products) and I also have no control after I have released your package for delivery. This is an estimate time and some packages may arrive sooner/later than others.***

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount of support that anyone could ever give is very much appreciated.

If you can share this campaign in any way, please do - and a big thank you to you!

Indiegogo has share tools available to share on other social media platforms.

You may also check or tag my main page on Instagram @oldstoriesph where I post all my updates and announcements outside of Indiegogo. Thank you so much!
story_txt:
HELLO EVERYONE
My name is Stacey. I am a full time artist who has dreamed of designing my very own enamel pin collection.
I started @oldstoriesph on Instagram as a way for me to share my art and designs to the world.
Starting this campaign is a big step closer to making my work as an artist into a brand that creates fun, collectible and wearable art through the help and support of people in this community.

Initial facts:
1. This is a FIXED funding campaign.
- No funds will be collected from backers if the minimum goal of $600 is NOT reached.
2. SURVEYS will be sent to all backers via e-mail when the campaign ends.
-This is very important that you remember to check if you have backed this project. This is where you will choose which designs you are ordering.
3. Please make sure to double-check your shipping information.
- To make sure that your pins arrive safely to the correct addresses. Thank you!
 

THE PINS
***3 designs are available from the start of the campaign. The Pegasus, Griffin, and Centaur.***
The other designs will unlock as goals are met.




All pins are hard enamel, 4-6 colors, gold plating, approximately 2" or less big and have 2 rubber backs to hold the pin secure. Backing card designs are also shown and will be wrapped in self adhesive clear plastic bags and extra bubble wrap.
 
FUNDS and REWARDS
To have enamel pins produced is a lengthy and costly process and can only be made using the funds from this campaign if the minimum goal is met. I will be shipping and managing everything from the Philippines, but I will be having them made outside of the country by a manufacturer that I trust with producing only high quality pins.
These funds go completely to:
- 85% Manufacturing and shipping.
- 10% Backing cards and packaging materials.
- 5% Indiegogo Fees.

(Image above- free individual stickers that come with any pin pledge. Get the sticker that corresponds to the design/s that you chose)
I have also prepared rewards for all backers who help me with this project. Please read each perk carefully to see which available rewards you prefer.
- Free individual sticker of your pin(s) of choice for all backers from the beginning.
- Early bird discounts.
- Reach $1200 in the campaign and everyone gets an exclusive postcard print of a painting I made just for this campaign.

story:
What is Otherworld Encounter?

Otherworld Encounter is a start-up company, creating an experience that the Nashville has never seen before! Our mission with Otherworld Encounter is to transport audiences into an interactive art fantasy land, introducing them to state of the art technologies in an approachable way.

Virtual reality, hologram technology, interactive projection mapping, and more, will be on display in a creative way; displaying original content created by the Otherworld team. Physical art installations that you can play with, touch, climb on, and be a part of, fill up the exhibit that is around 10,000 square feet. This immersive experience centers itself around a science fiction story line, with an element of mystery incorporated by hidden clues scattered around the exhibit. Can you find all of the clues and gain access to a top-secret room?

Otherworld Encounter has been created by a group of local Nashville talent, going by the name of Nashville's OWN (OtherWorld Network). With backgrounds in fine art, app development, digital animation, festival art, marketing and branding, event production, and more; the OtherWorld Network is filled to the brim with brilliance from all different backgrounds. From the beginning, one of the most important principles that Otherworld Encounter exists on is the necessity to compensate artists for their time and work. We are changing the narrative of "starving artists," by providing individual grants to every artist, as well as a percentage of profit sharing to the entire collective.

Since the beginning of our build in October 2018, Otherworld Encounter has contributed $100k directly to the employment and contracting of creatives.

And now we need your help!

Contributing to the Otherworld Encounter Community Fund is contributing to the creative economy of Nashville. This fund will allow us to keep providing paid opportunities for local artists, as well as bring a never-before-seen experience to a creative community that is already being established as one of the top in the country.

Introducing Nashville's OWN (OtherWorld Network):

Alex Patin * AnnaLee LeNoir-Kelly * Brian Somerville * Chris Strachan * Earl Washington-Kelly * Jamie Whitlow * Jessi Knight * Joseph Newsome * Julien Foster * Kay Kennedy * K.C. Whitlow * Matt Kinney * Ralph Edge * Sandor Torgyik * Sheila Whitlow * Taylor Matson

About the Otherworld Encounter Community Fund.

The Otherworld Encounter team plans to utilize the funding we gain through the Otherworld Encounter Community Fund towards several key aspects of continuing the project.

Thus far in the development of Otherworld Encounter, we have used personal funding towards aspects such as:

- Legal and professional fees such as an attorney, LLC formation, conferences, financial consultation, and banking.

- Venue rental and insurance for winter exhibit in Nashville and spring exhibit in Atlanta.

- Workshop space for build of exhibit.

- Storage and transportation.

- Grant and employment compensation.

With the $20,000 we aim to raise through the Otherworld Encounter Community Fund, we plan to pay for:

- Materials and equipment to continue the growth and improvement of the exhibit, including adding additional rooms, involving additional technological elements, and building upon rooms already within the exhibit.

- Marketing for July exhibit in Nashville.

- Continued employment and contracting of local artists.

- Venue rentals and transportation costs for future exhibits throughout the Southeast, including Nashville show in July.

YOUR contribution is not only directly helping us improve the exhibit, but is allowing Nashville artists to CREATE, LEARN, and EARN with Otherworld Encounter!

Aside from contributing to the creative community in Nashville, you will receive some unique and amazing perks, such as limited edition Otherworld Encounter merchandise, a chance to be featured within the exhibit, and even private events especially for you from Otherworld Encounter!

In the event that we do not reach our $20,000 goal, we still plan to follow through and continue to grow the Otherworld Encounter exhibit! The funds we do raise will go primarily towards marketing of the event, and compensation for artists and employees.

Other ways you can help:

Can't contribute financially right now? That's okay! Help us get the word out about Otherworld Encounter by spreading the word about our event and campaign!

Every time our campaign is shared and viewed, it helps bring us higher within our category, with more opportunity to be seen by potential donors!

Tell your friends about this awesome event that will be coming back to Nashville, and tag #otherworldencounter!

If you are interested in working with Otherworld Encounter, e-mail us at otherworldencounter@gmail.com with your information, and we will put you to work!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT IN MAKING THE GROWTH OF OTHERWORLD ENCOUNTER A REALITY!

story:
Introduction

We are the BAM! Toronto Youth Slam Team for 2012-2013, otherwise known as BTdot. We consist of many talented poets with many accolades and slams under their belt. We have been invited to compete at Youth Speaks - Brave New Voices 2013 in Chicago! With the help of our coaches Brian Millado, Patrick De Belen and Marcus Lomboy, we're hoping to bring crazy fire to Chicago this year at Brave New Voices and the other events we hope to competing at! This is a dream come true for all of our poets and we would appreciate any help that you can provide to help us get there! 

Here is a little bit about our members:

Saredo Mohamed is a 17 year old poet from London, Ontario, Canada. She ventured into spoken word poetry in Grade 11, where she continued to present and compete at BAM! Toronto Youth Slam. Saredo became the BAM! Toronto Youth Slam Grand Slam Champion for the 2012-2013 season, and has been featured in an article by Metro newspaper. Saredo uses her experiences with race, immigration and travel as inspiration for her work, and hopes to inspire others with her poetry.

Ray Abergas is an 18 year old poet from Scarborough, Ontario, Canada. He is also the captain of the BAM! Toronto Youth Poetry Slam team, BTdot. He combines his relentless passion of helping others, poetry and performance to mold the person he is today. Ray has performed for a number of organizations like UNITY charity, UNIFFECT, Kapisanan Philippine Centre for Arts and Culture and RISE poetry. When asked about why he loves spoken word poetry, he replies: "I think words can save lives and that's what I want to do".

Jacob Agustin, better known as his stage name JaayRoyy. He is an 18 year old spoken word poet and rapper, born and raised in Toronto, Ontario. He writes because he not only loves the adrenaline he gets on stage and the freedom he feels when expressing himself but to also change lives and influence positive attitudes, especially to youth. Jacob is an active member in UNIFFECT and UNITY charity.

Hailing from Toronto, Ontario, Karel La Guardia is climbing his way up among the top youth poets in his city. His writing style is largely influenced by his personal experiences. Trying to take inspiration from all his surroundings, his poetry can take you along a journey about his ambitions, his struggles, and maybe even his breakfast (most likely his breakfast). When he's not gracing the stage with his poetry, Karel is an avid music listener, video game junkie, and works toward getting his high school diploma and ultimately into the field of teaching. Karel's passion for music, poetry, and bacon composes his whole being (but mostly bacon).

At the age of 17, Berma is a wordsmith who's passion cannot be questioned. As a member of Spoken Ward, UNIFFECT, and BTdot, he has honed his ability to perform and enjoys spilling his soul on the stage. At a young age, Berma encountered many hardships only to come out stronger. He uses his words to speak out on issues that affected him and to help those who are dealing with the same things. Whether its talking about sports, music, or even the weather, Berma is a character that can't be missed.

Blaze is a poet from Guelph, Ontario, Canada. She became involved with Guelph Spoken Word at a young age and has not looked back ever since. She is one of the youngest poets to ever represent a team on national stage. She has also organized and hosted many youth festivals such as Youth in Unison and Inferno festival where the main event is a giant team poetry slam.

 

The Breakdown

The $1500 that we hope to raise will go towards:
- Event Registration Fees (Fun fact: Brave New Voices, the largest youth slam festival in the world, has a $1250 team registration fee alone!)
- Transportation
- Lodging
- Food, supplies, etc. 

Funds collected will be divided up towards the fees (registration, lodging, travel, etc.) of the following spoken word events and festivals:
- Youth In Unison 2: June 29 (Guelph)
- SLAMtario: July 12-13 (Toronto)
- Brave New Voices: August 7-11 (Chicago)
- Canadian Festival of Spoken Word YouthCanSlam: August 20-25 (Ottawa)
- And more to be announced!

 

The Impact

Spoken word poetry is an artform that almost anybody can do and is accessible to everyone. You don't even need a pen and paper. All you need are your thoughts. Spoken word poetry can cover any issue: race, violence, immigration, you name it. Your voice is the most powerful tool that you can ever use. As poets, we want to show youth that you can use poetry to save yourselves from the problems that you have on a daily basis. Spoken word poetry saves lives, and some of our poets are living examples of that. 

By supporting us, you're helping us show the world our voices. You're supporting a cause that is trying to change lives for the better and maybe even save a life. We are trying to raise awareness on topics that we feel aren't getting enough attention, as well as telling our stories and the stories of people who have inspired us and moved us in so many ways. 

Other Ways You Can Help

- Follow us on twitter! twitter.com/BTdot for future updates!
- Spread the word! Word of mouth is the best way to raise awareness!
- Check us out on Youtube! Youtube.com/user/SpokenWard ! Like, comment, share, subscribe! Any help will be greatly appreciated!
- Share this page! We can use all the help we can get! 

 

SUPPORT THE B.TDOT / BAM! TORONTO YOUTH POETRY SLAM TEAM OF 2012-2013!

story:
WHO WE ARE:

“Art Day Celebration,” is a creative art program of Diakonos International 501(c)(3) that cultivates and empowers impoverished and underprivileged children in Haiti. Our mission is to bring healing, restore hope and nurture the spirits of poverty-stricken children through the arts, building a platform where they can showcase their artistry. The goal of Art Day Celebration is to provide children from poor communities and developing countries access to quality visual and performing arts in the four domains of creative art; Music, Movement, Art, and Drama.

 

The “Art on Canvas” annual event workshop in July is designed to nurture underprivileged children through explorations of the creative art in the painting. 

Now in its second year, “Art on Canvas” is looking to fulfill the children’s expectation shaped by their experiences during our inaugural year. Utilizing the arts to bring hope through creativity, ADC team works together with disenfranchised children to guide them into exploring various forms of art and developing an appreciation for life through a series of art activities which offer opportunities to:

  • Provide them a new set of skills for self-expression and communication.
  • Discover their creative abilities and develop their individual artistic talent.
    • Use the analytical skills learned to empower them to blossom into fully functional, self-reliant and productive members of their society.
    • Motivate them to find their purpose in life.

The Community will also benefit from sponsored fundraising art exhibitions to help develop sustainable projects and establish a scholarship fund for participating children. 85% of the sale of each child’s original artwork benefits the children directly and their education costs. 

 

Last year's (2012) “Art on Canvas” workshop had close to 150 children from orphanages, tent cities, and local underprivileged children in the city of Carrefour.  The 2 day event held at the Centre de Sportif de in Carrefour was packed with painting, dancing, a D.J., Haiti news presence, eating and pure fun.. We had 13 U.S. volunteers including the ADC core team and Professional Teacher Artists, Haiti Artist Volunteers and local volunteers. 

SOME BACKGROUND INFORMATION:

Art Day Celebration is a program for Diakonos International 501(c)(3), that offers a fresh and dynamic approach to help confront the orphan and homeless crisis in Haiti through the creation of a Family Home called “KOMINOTE TI FANMI NOU de DIAKONOS” (meaning “Our small Community of Family”). The home provides a safe family haven for orphans, abandoned, homeless and rejected children where they can play, learn, grow and develop into healthy, happy, educated and productive adults who will become the next generation of Haitian citizens.  Located in a rural town of Port-au-Prince called Carrefour and residence to well over 20 children, the home is at the heart of our mission. 

Diakonos’ pioneer Wilfrid Longchamp had been a Diaspora living in California as a Computer programmer and after being diagnosed with an autoimmune disease, he decided to move to Haiti by the encouragement of his sister Martine Longchamp, Co-Founder of Diakonos. There he saw the need to provide the street children with access to a quality life. Unfortunately, Wilfrid did not live to see the full fruition of his vision as he perished in the 2010 Earthquake while establishing the Diakonos Orphanage. His body has not been recovered. But his legacy will live through Diakonos International  and Art Day Celebration.

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP NOW: 

Art is a tool that can help rebuild a community and can have a major impact in a child’s life. The children who participated last year keep asking when ADC is coming back. The program is in need of funding to cover the costs of  the logistics of operating the “Art on Canvas”- 2013 workshop.  Our exhibit/fundriasing efforts has raised over $700 towards the participating children's education but not enough for the continutation of this years 'Art on Canvas'. We desperately need your help:

Your financial contribution will help enable us to:

Purchase Art Kits for 150 orphans (water color paint, acrylic paint, brushes, canvas paper, pallattes)- A Reeves box set for each child to keep

Cover the cost of Food and Water to feed all children participants and volunteers throughout the duration the art program.

Cover the rental costs of location, chairs, and tables for the lcoation the art workshop

Lodging, transportation on the ground and air for supplies and ADC volunteer artists, and participants

Shipment costs of Artwork being brough to the U.S for preparation of showcasing exhibit

Framing costs of selected Artwork to showcase

Your contribution will also go to cover other necessary costs, such as:

Preparation for our next quarterly workshop in the Art of Dance, with a professional notable choreographer

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

  • Please spread the word to continue the support for our art program! 
  • Become a sponsor and donate towards our creative art workshops on a monthly basis.
  • Interested in teaching your creative talent within the Arts? We are always looking for qualified volunteers to help facilitate workshops for ADC in Haiti

Please find more information about us:

Our website: http://artdaycelebration.org

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ArtDayCelebration
