story:
Ritual Abuse Tarot is a dark, satirical tarot deck featuring 78 original charcoal illustrations by Ryan Sheffield (me). The project was created as an homage to artist Stephen Gammell (Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark), who gave me a childhood's-worth of nightmares and, most importantly, inspired me to make art. 


Click here to see all 78 cards.


The first pressing of the deck was funded through a successful Kickstarter campaign last year and I hope to keep this labor of love alive in a second pressing!


Where the Money Will Go

Unfortunately the production cost of the decks is rather high and I don't have the personal resources to fund it on my own. I am hoping to use this campaign to cover the cost of production. Any and all profit made from the campaign will be used to produce additional copies of the deck. 

The $5000 goal would cover the cost of 300 copies, but the funding on the campaign is flexible, so even if the goal isn't reached, all backers will still receive their perks!

The Deck

The Ritual Abuse Tarot includes:

  • 78 tarot cards, professionally-printed on high-quality linen stock
  • a metal tin labeled with sleek vinyl stickers
  • a 22-page instruction booklet

I assemble, label, cut & staple each copy by hand.


Perks


Signed Art Prints:

If you choose this perk, let me know which card's artwork you'd like for your print. Click here to see all the cards.
I make the prints one-at-a-time on 90lb. textured paper, sign/date them, and put them in archival plastic sleeves with chipboard backing. They'll ship flat and well-secured. 
 NOTE: The art prints do not include the card border or text. Click here to see an example.

Posters:

If you choose a perk that includes a poster, let me know which card's artwork you'd like for your poster. Click here to see all the cards.
I make the prints one-at-a-time on high-quality satin poster paper and sign/date each one. They are carefully rolled with tissue paper and placed in a plastic poster sleeve. The rolled poster ships in a sturdy poster tube. 
NOTE: Just like the art prints, the posters do not include the card border or text. Click here to see a framed poster of The Moon.

Custom Drawing:

If you choose the perk that includes a custom drawing, simply let me know what you'd like me to draw for you. We can discuss it in depth and make sure it's exactly what you want. The custom artwork will be done in charcoal on 11x14" bristol paper in the same art style as the cards. The completed drawing will ship flat and well-secured. I can also email you a high-resolution digital scan of the drawing if you'd like. 


Risks & Challenges

Since the project is entirely complete aside from printing/assembly, the only foreseeable setbacks would involve production/shipping delays on the part of the manufacturers I'm working with. I used the same companies for the first pressing and had nothing but good results, so I don't anticipate there will be any issues. On the off-chance that any setbacks do occur, backers will be notified immediately. I've maintained a 5-star seller rating on Etsy for several years and I have a team of wonderful family & friends who are kind enough to pitch-in if I need any help keeping on schedule.

story:
My name is Chase Wood and I’m an illustrator and designer out of Long Beach, CA. I recently finished a poster design called “Dominance” depicting one of NBA’s most dynamic characters, DeAndre Jordan. With the ongoing success of the respected and likable player, the time felt right to craft artwork inspired by the athlete's dominating presence on the court. The poster glorifies the fearless energy of the LA Clippers’ center through a team oriented color scheme, emotionally expressive subject matter, and a kinetic composition.

I am aiming to raise enough funds to produce a limited run of 200 posters. The funds will cover the cost of production and shipping to all of the sports enthusiasts that contribute.

 

Basics

  • The funds raised will cover screen print production of 200 prints and shipping.

Tier Breakdown

Digital Download - Contribute $10

Poster Purchase - Contribute $40

story:
Welcome To Feast Arts Center:

Hi!  My name is Chandler Woodfin.  My husband Todd Jannausch and I are the co-founders of an exciting new art venture —Feast Arts Center in Tacoma, Washington.  We are both practicing artists and have for a long time seen a need for a stronger relationship between art and community.   The guiding concept at Feast is the belief that community involvement enriches personal experience, that personal experience informs art-making, and that art-making strengthens communities.  So how do we do that?  Well, we believe that we achieve this by providing a place where community and art-making can merge.

Community:

Feast acts as a platform providing free community events on an ongoing basis.  These events allow everyone the opportunity to participate with art and their community in some way.  They will include things like free meals, supplies and studio time to those in need, outdoor movies nights in the summertime, and free artist lectures.

Classes:

At the heart of it all is art-making.  Feast will offer a variety of art classes taught by local and regional professional artists.  These will include ongoing multi week classes, weekend workshops, critiques, lectures and after school programs for youth and adults working at all levels.

Gallery:

The Gallery at Feast will highlight the work of local and regional artists.  It will also be a way to encourage dialog and interaction between established artists and new emerging artists who may be taking their very first art class. 

What We Need:

$25,000

With your donation, we can make Feast Arts Center become a reality.  This money will go directly towards:

Class Supplies

Easels

Stackable Stools

Folding Tables 

Metal Storage Cabinet

Plastic organizer bins

Standing Lamps

First Aid Kits

Hazardous Materials Locker 

Drawing Boards

 Flat Files

Benches for Worktable 

Plastic Deep Sinks

Shelving 

Storage Racks for Drawing Boards

Movable Chalkboard Wall

Tech Support

Projector

Screen

Printer         

Tablet  

Quickbooks  

Website Construction

Logo Design

Art Supplies

Paper

Tape

Charcoal

Paints 

Brushes 

Cups and Jars

Scissors

Paper Cutters

Straight Edges

Copy Machine

Exterior 

Building Paint

Sign Paint

Vinyl

Window Replacement

2 Sandwich Boards  

Galvanized Light  

Parking Lot Repairs

Interior

Sand and Finish Concrete Floors

Bathroom Remodel

Paperwork

Business License  

Insurance

Who We Are:

Todd Jannausch:

Todd is a sculptor, installation artist and co-founder of Feast Arts Center. Between 2010-2014 he created a series of installations that allowed artists to interact with the community and show art in new ways. His work has been shown at The Frye Art Museum, The Bellevue Art Museum and he was the recipient of a 2015 Artist Trust Fellowship. He has spent the last five years working as a program manager and art instructor at Pratt Fine Arts Center. toddjannausch.com  

Chandler Woodfin:

Chandler is a draftsman, painter and co-founder of Feast Arts Center. She received her BFA in painting from Columbia College and completed a 2 year apprenticeship program at Gage Academy of art in Seattle. She has been teaching drawing and painting for 5 years at places such as Pratt Fine Arts Center, Gage Academy of Art, and Kirkland Art Center. Check out her work here: chandlerwoodfin.com

Bottom Line:

Feast is an impassioned project created and lead by two people who believe wholeheartedly in the impact a place like Feast Arts Center can have on a community.  We need your help to make this happen.  We know that not everyone can make a financial contribution, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.  Please spread the word any way you can, and thank you for supporting us!

story:
Our Story

ANUBIS is a 50' high wooden combustible sculpture for Burning Man 2012.  We are raising money to build, ship and reassemble at Black Rock City for the Burning Man Festival 2012.  We will build the piece at NIMBY in Oakland, CA with a team volunteers.  This money is to be used solely for construction materials and construction space leasing.  No individual compensation for labor or expertise is being levied or paid through this project.

The Artist: Dan Fox was the Prinicpal Builder and Construction Coordinator for the Trojan Horse Project for Burning Man 2011.

The Architect: Dan Swain was the Principal Architect for the Trojan Horse Project.

The Construction Lead: Jake Clinkenbeard was a key carpenter and and a vital part of the on-playa assembly team for the Trojan Horse Project.

The Builders: Many of the same key builders of the Trojan Horse are signed up and have already been on site to help with the construction of the head, including Chris Webb, the Project Lead for the Trojan Horse Project, and Michael DeGroot, a key member of the NIMBY and on-playa build team.

Many new faces are signed up and have already participated in building and supporting Anubis.  We are excited and ready!

The Impact

We will burn this sculpture on playa, Friday night, August 31, 2012, in a spectacle of a fast and hot flame and pyrotechnics.  We will have physical fundraising events to bring the sculpture to the playa. 

What We Need & What You Get

Construction Materials - $9,500.00

  • 4 x 4s & dimensional lumber
  • plywood 
  • clips, brackets, holdowns
  • nails, screws, bolts
  • LED lighting
  • Carbon Offsets 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can donate directly via Paypal, you can buy materials directly, you can come to NIMBY and help build this by signing up on our volunteer list!

Google docs volunteer sign up sheet:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dG50RHRBaTlmallDVWpPeHJ1VFpTSlE6MQ#gid=0

story:
Representing the culmination of work and research by Goldsmiths’ Image and Communication postgraduate students, the 2011 IC SHOW will be a dynamic exhibition of London’s up and coming new-media artists.

This year, we have the privilege of displaying our works in Goldsmith’s recently constructed, state-of-the-art media building and boast the largest and most culturally diverse group of students to undertake this program. Now is your chance to get involved in our quest to create another successful showcase of creative talent. The funds will be used to hire equipment, create prints and purchase various supplies needed for student work.


In return for support of this 'must-see' event, you will associate yourselves with Goldsmiths College—an institution known internationally for its Arts tradition—and have the opportunity to assist emerging artists and designers at a pivotal moment in their careers.

Made up of 30 young artists from diverse backgrounds and nationalities, the MA Image and Communication students work in media ranging from photography and film to animation and interactive installation.  Inquiries are welcome -- please contact us at exhibition.goldsmiths@gmail.com


And spread the word!!

Now is your chance to get involved in our quest to create another successful showcase of creative talent. The funds will be used to hire equipment, create prints and purchase various supplies needed for student work.


In return for support of this 'must-see' event, you will associate yourselves with Goldsmiths College—an institution known internationally for its Arts tradition—and have the opportunity to assist emerging artists and designers at a pivotal moment in their careers.Made up of 30 young artists from diverse backgrounds and nationalities, the MA Image and Communication students work in media ranging from photography and film to animation and interactive installation.  Inquiries are welcome -- please contact us at exhibition.goldsmiths@gmail.com

And spread the word!!

story:
I, Michael Guy Allen (MGA) am a dreamer with many hats; Broadcast Journalist, videographer, childcare provider, combat veteran, actor...  I am moving to Los Angeles, CA later this Winter to further pursue my acting career.  I am, with great humility, asking for financial assistance.  I hope to raise a mere $1,000 to help me arrive in LA on my feet.  Of course, going under or over, especially over, the proposed goal is ok; anything helps.  My fundriasing goal may be modest, but my dream is glamorous, and my talent is real.  This time when I go to war, I'm going to war with YOU at my side; the war on failure.  I know only together can success be achieved.  And I promise upon the success of this campian you will not only make a star, but you will have changed the future for dreamers everywhere.  Because this success will prove dreamers can be doers, and in turn every dreamer is a star.

What I ask for -

$1,000+ to assist with moving expenses, and potentially provide career aid only.

  • Including but not limited to: travel, further reel distribution, casting registration(s), acting classes, etc...

What YOU get -

Contributors will receive various incentives personally handled by MGA.

  • Thank you messages & videos (private/public)
  • Autographed photos
  • Copies of MGA's reel
  • Copies of MGA's Afghanistan Adventure videos personally shot & edited by him during his tour in Afghanistan
  • Access to exclusive career based photos, videos & updates

 

The Impact

As a "neapolitan" of experiences wrapped in an entertaining personality, my goal in all I do is to instill within my audiences and supporters the idea that you can do anything, your own way, and spread passion like fire among the masses.  To be inspired is to be inspiring.  This is my promise as an entertainer and as person: I will be inspiring, not only to artists, but to everyone, because people deserve to have their belief rewarded.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, spread the word of my campaign, my dream, and my drive.  Feel free to contact me and share your thoughts and or stories of heartbreak and triumph.  DoDream.

story: The Icons and Demigods series is an on-going project of pop and counter-culture images from the second half of the 20th century that have shaped artist and chamelon Michael Venus' (and his drag alter ego Miss Cotton's) work. Inspired by real life and fictional iconic characters, the Photographs serve as a time capsule that captures the essence of familiar imagery while dealing with issues of gender, sexuality, celebrity and more. Since the begining the efforts have always been collaboarative with a variety photographers, make-up artists and graphic designers. The series has been co-sponsored by Club Card Printing who have put out thousands of the different postcards since the very piece "Farrah Fawcett". The cards have made their way around the globe and even into some of the hands of the Icons themselves. Bruce LaBruce even photographed his own tribute image. In 2003 One Point Six Gallery in Vancouver hosted the debut exhibit entitled "Venus Rising" which had 18 images and was covered by Fashion Television. In 2010, The Grace Gallery did an Icons and Demigods show with over 50 peices and videos. The entire project has never had funding and has, to date, relied on thye donated time and talent of various collaborators. In order to continue devloping the ongoing series further, we are hoping to garner the basic costs associated with new work. Any money raised will cover expences for sets, costumes and to pay the contributers working on the shoot. With your support, the project can continue with new images and be exhibition-ready for upcoming shows and an eventual coffee table book. WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU'LL GET We are hoping to raise $5000.00 to create 15 more pictures to cover minimum expences from beginning to end. We gratefully accept all donations but with any $100.00 and up you will recieve an 8.5 by 11 signed image of your choice of existing images. For $500.00 or more you get a signed autograph and additionally, you can choose from and icon from the list below who you would like to see be re-created first. New image possibilities include: Cindy Lauper Kate Bush Bauhaus Kylie Minogue Pet Shop Boys General Idea Dianna Ross Joni Mitchell Prince Madonna Skinny Puppy Twiggy Elvira John Waters Divine Twink Peaks Joe Dellesandro Peter Berlin Whiteney Houston I Dream of Genie Missing Persons The Ramones The B-52's Gordan Lightfoot The Sisters of Mercy Mink Stole Candy Darling Stevie Wonder Mick Jagger Jerry Hall Wham Cindy Sherman Alanis Morrisette Elvis James Brown We Can Do It National Geographic Dukes of Hazzard Nash The Slash Gary Newman Mitsou Wayne Gretzsky Peter Gabriel RuPaul Michael Alig Lady Bunny Brooke Shields Sweenie SIsters Scott Thompson David Suzuki Platunim Blonde Super Girl Michael- Arch Angel Splash Birth of Venus Bonnie and Clyde Janet Jackson

story:
Art is the heart and soul of a community.  And in no place that we know of, is that more true than on Whidbey Island. It’s a place of breathtaking natural beauty, with a community that is as rich in art and culture, as it is in tall trees, open farmland, and sweeping water views. Whidbey Life Magazine is our voice.



Whidbey Life Magazine provides visitors and residents with a rich online resource for arts and cultural events. Every week we have new feature stories about our artists, local food, and performances. There is a daily calendar of events. Because of the interest in Whidbey’s visual arts, theater, and music, from around the entire region, a printed magazine would bring greater awareness of all  that our island has to offer.


In a small community, the local economy is literally our lifeblood, and arts and culture play a big part.  In the last 40 years, visual artists, writers, actors, dancers, farmers, and chefs have followed their hearts here. These creative professionals have not only contributed to the great quality of life here, they’ve also contributed to our local economy.

We attract visitors from Canada, Washington, Oregon, California, Idaho and Europe, drawn by our reputation for beautiful views, comfortable weather, exciting events, local foods, numerous art schools and writing retreats. In 2012, more than $13 million was spent on art work at galleries and individual artists' studios, 25% higher than the national average. Much of this income goes right back into the local economy.

But to those of us who live here, art doesn't just exist as something to hang on a  wall. We are also rich in local farms, farmers markets, restaurants and people to whom food is also an art form.

Whidbey Life Magazine began as a way to inform all of Whidbey Island's residents and visitors about the rich cultural life available to residents and visitors. Founded by Sue Taves and Jan Shannon, WLM has been successfully publishing it's online magazine since July of 2012. In a little over one year WLM has grown and now has over 10,000 visits a month to the online magazine. We send a weekly WLM Flash email newsletter to over 1450 avid readers.

Our popularity has grown, our readers and fans pushed us to a #2 spot in the King 5/Best of Western Washington contest this fall for "Best Neighborhood Blog" in the region over 78 other websites! 

Our readership is growing, but we believe that we can further increase it by offering a twice yearly print version of our magazine. Being in print would also give us the opportunity to reach visitors who like to "unplug" when they step on the ferry to our quiet island.

WHERE’S THE MONEY GOING?

We’re asking for $8250 to jump-start the print version of Whidbey Life Magazine. The print magazine will work hand in hand with the ever-changing online magazine.

We Need Funds For:
  • Creating a template for layout and design
  • Printing 2500 magazines
  • Administrative support for the project
  • Advertising/Promotion/Distribution

The money we raise with this campaign will cover 30-40% of the costs for the first year. We will raise the other funds through advertising, paid subscriptions, sponsorship and partnerships and grants. The more money we raise the more magazines we can print and distribute. If we exceed our goal, we can add more pages of content to the magazine.

Timeline:

We will spend the winter developing the template and creating the content, with a projected publication date in early spring. The first issue will focus
on Spring/Summer and a second fall/winter issue, printed in September.

If we don't meet our goal...

... we will decide between creating an inaugural 16-page (instead of 24-page) magazine or we'll postpone our launch date and take more time to raise funds from advertisers, donors and partners and work toward a first edition Summer/Fall magazine.

The Impact

The more people there are who read about the arts when they visit Whidbey, translates to a more sustainable income for the creative community. This in turn benefits our community as a whole.

Here's a podcast from Whidbey Air radio station, that tells about the beginnings of WLM and it's evolution from it's early days as a social media site for visual artists: Artists Sue Taves & Robbie Lobell - Isle of the Arts

Sue Taves is an artist with a passion for stone sculpting, the Whidbey community and collaboration. She’s lived onWhidbey since 2004, carves fine art sculpture at the Freeland Art Studios and likes to bring people and ideas together. Her efforts to develop a central resource for the Arts on Whidbey was supported and brought to life by the talents of her partner and spouse, Jan Shannon. Jan spent years in the Silicon Valley working with computers before the days of laptops and certainly before there was a glimmer of a twitter in anyone’s eye. She  developed the website and drives all things technical for WLM. Our editor, Patricia Duff, is our fearless leader when it comes to content. Having written for the local newspaper she is well-acquainted with the arts community and involved as an artist herself in the theater and literary communities of Whidbey. She started as the only writer and blogger for WLM and now manages a team of 5 other writers, 11 bloggers, our gifted staff photographer David Welton, and Anne Belov, our Virtual Gallery curator.

For more about us and our team see our About Us page on WLM.

People to Whom We Are Most Grateful...

...Our readers and avid fans. Of course, our members who not only make for an endless supply of great stories, they also contribute news and events to our magazine in our “News from our Members” and our Calendar. We couldn't survive without our advertising partners and sponsors. Thank you for the value that you place on our contribution to the  community of Whidbey Island. We wouldn't be here if it wasn't for the generosity of our benefactor and initial donors, thank you from the bottom of our hearts. A giant thank you to the WLM members who have donated one of a kind perks that will be popping up throughout the campaign!

Thanks to the photographers who shared their photographs with us to make our campaign fun and colorful! David Welton photographed the annual Goosefoot Mutt Strut  (just one of the fun community events around here) and the luscious purple onions. We have Sandy Rubini to thank for the evocative photo of Siri Bardarson playing the cello in an...um....rather untraditional way.

WLM MISSION;

To create a primarily online source of arts and culture news and information that promotes all the arts and artists of Whidbey, makes the arts more accessible to the public and promotes arts and cultural visits to the island thereby providing economic stimulus to the Whidbey community.  

WLM is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non profit art service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Whidbey Life Magazine must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. This campaign figures out all of that for you and you'll see in the "Perks" that part of each donation is tax deductible, and the amount not deductible is noted in each perk description. Perks with no tangible reward are completely tax deductible.

Here's the short list of WLM members who have generously donated their products and services to our campaign.  You can read more about them in our updates!

NEW PERKS:
Anastasia Brencick: Massage!!
Creativity Coaching with professional coach (and WLM blogger) Deb Lund
Brunch and Paddleboarding on Whidbey
Anne Belov - The Panda Chronicles Books 1 through 3
John Auburn of  JW Desserts - Delectable cupcakes
Saratoga Orchestra of Whidbey Island - Season passes to their 2014 season.
Cook on Clay - Flameproof cookware
Sweet Mona's - Chocolates! - SOLD OUT!
Braeburn - Breakfast or Lunch: SOLD OUT

OutCast Productions - A season pass for 2 to their 2014 season
Jam from Judith Walcutt!- She writes AND makes excellent jam!-SOLD OUT!
Ironpeace - steel peace sign fabricated by welder Jim Bernacki
Richard Evans - "Harry Monument" DVD, 8/10 on IMDB!!
Little Brown Farm - Get the secret recipe for Laughing Bellies Toffee!

See more "Perks" below:

David Welton - Printed photograph of "Moonrise over Langley," (pictured below)


Design Consultation by design stylist (and WLM blogger) Julie Cunha

 


Other ways you can help

Please help us by telling others about WLM and our campaign

Use the Indiegogo share buttons on this page
Sign up for our FREE weekly WLM Flash email newsletter
Follow us on Facebook and Twitter
Share our WLM cards with your friends or put them out at your business

story:
A massive thank you to all of you that have donated so generously! 

For further updates and questions please visit our Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/AfrikaBurnFireCollective

 

Much love and dust

 

 

Imagine it: a playground of extraordinary creatures in the greatest fire show. A life-size T-Rex roars across the desert playa while boxing bunnies, swimming polar bears, hopeless headless chickens, propelling pterodactyls, haunting hyenas and a 60-foot pendulum swing to the beat. All alive and burning.

After wowing the AfrikaBurn community with the show in May this year, the AfrikaBurn Fire Collective is ready to take the show to Burning Man - and we need your help in getting it there. We are transporting our sculptures and our crew from Cape Town all the way to Black Rock City, Nevada, and it's going to be one heck of a swim, if not for YOU! 

Support us – we will shower you in love for it (or in grease, if that’s your thing!)

About us

The AfrikaBurn Fire Collective is a slightly feral, renegade group of blacksmiths, engineers, artists, carpenters, photographers and others from the AfrikaBurn organisation in South Africa. We like making extraordinary things and love to share our creations with the world.

Our mission is to take our flaming spectacular, distinctly AfrikaBurn-style, sculptural performance VLAM STOF (Flame & Dust) Odd-I-See from the dusty desert in South Africa all the way to Burning Man in 2013.

 More about the show

A blazing opera of fantastical flaming sculptures dancing under the stars, in a performance that is both magnificently playful and deeply touching.

The narrative is a cheeky evocation of a primordial struggle: our smithies conjure up a set of earth-creatures of steel and fire to battle it out over limited resources.  The pieces are ignited in a moving, playful chain‐reaction of fire, framed by a 60-foot high spinning pendulum blazing a beautiful arc of sparks through the night sky. Lizzy, a giant flaming T-Rex built out of scrap metal, emerges from an egg while two metal rabbits engage in a boxing match over a fallen carrot nearby. Joining in the theatrics is a flaming polar bear swimming for his life, pterodactyls, hyenas, headless chickens and more.

What We Need

We need money to share these magic creatures and their show with the world. We’ve been honoured to receive an art grant from Burning Man to help us in our quest, and we are holding fundraising events in South Africa. However as we watch our currency plummet and jet fuel prices go up, we admit our budgetary limitations, and need to appeal for more.

Besides the materials for the sculptures, our major cost is moving the sculptures from one side of the planet to the other – from Cape Town, South Africa to Nevada, USA.   

 All funds go directly to AfrikaBurn Creative Projects, a not-for-profit organization. (South African reg no 2007/020812/08) – please see our website for more info on the organization and annual accounts. 

 

About Afrikaburn:

AfrikaBurn is the 7-year-old African regional offshoot of Burning Man. It’s a fabulous example of how the ethos of Burning Man has spread across the globe.  We are keen to share our particular flaming madness with the main Burning Man event, whilst building bridges between our continents and making friends on our global collective playgrounds.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Spam your friends and family and send out the Indiegogo link.

Like and spread our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/AfrikaBurnFireCollective

 We can’t wait to set our creatures free in the desert - to dance, swim, run, fight, play… and burn!

Thank you amazing, wonderful people.

From the AfrikaBurn Fire Collective

 More about the show
A blazing opera of fantastical flaming sculptures dancing under the stars, in a performance that is both magnificently playful and deeply touching.
The narrative is a cheeky evocation of a primordial struggle: our smithies conjure up a set of earth-creatures of steel and fire to battle it out over limited resources.  The pieces are ignited in a moving, playful chain‐reaction of fire, framed by a 60-foot high spinning pendulum blazing a beautiful arc of sparks through the night sky. Lizzy, a giant flaming T-Rex built out of scrap metal, emerges from an egg while two metal rabbits engage in a boxing match over a fallen carrot nearby. Joining in the theatrics is a flaming polar bear swimming for his life, pterodactyls, hyenas, headless chickens and more.
What We Need
We need money to share these magic creatures and their show with the world. We’ve been honoured to receive an art grant from Burning Man to help us in our quest, and we are holding fundraising events in South Africa. However as we watch our currency plummet and jet fuel prices go up, we admit our budgetary limitations, and need to appeal for more.
Besides the materials for the sculptures, our major cost is moving the sculptures from one side of the planet to the other – from Cape Town, South Africa to Nevada, USA.   
 All funds go directly to AfrikaBurn Creative Projects, a not-for-profit organization. (South African reg no 2007/020812/08) – please see our website for more info on the organization and annual accounts. 
 
About Afrikaburn:
AfrikaBurn is the 7-year-old African regional offshoot of Burning Man. It’s a fabulous example of how the ethos of Burning Man has spread across the globe.  We are keen to share our particular flaming madness with the main Burning Man event, whilst building bridges between our continents and making friends on our global collective playgrounds.
 
Other Ways You Can Help:
Spam your friends and family and send out the Indiegogo link.
Like and spread our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/AfrikaBurnFireCollective
 We can’t wait to set our creatures free in the desert - to dance, swim, run, fight, play… and burn!
Thank you amazing, wonderful people.
From the AfrikaBurn Fire Collective

story:
Hello...

I'm Helen Bird. I'm an artist.

I grew up in England, loved comic books and horse riding.

My Mum was a decorative artist & a photographer.

  She was, still is a true inspiration!

'Go, go and amuse yourself!' She would tell me.

So, I'd imagine up all kinds of places. And draw them.

  I came to the US over 20 years ago.

I kinda knew I always would.

 I discovered a love of new places

 and was 'bit' by a nomadic bug early on in life...

A wide eyed travel nurse ready for an adventure.

 What better way than to head West to America.

 I specialized in Pediatric Oncology Nursing,

a calling that

prepared me in so many ways for a life

 devoted to compassion, care and love for

our fellow humans...big or small.

I quit nursing about three years ago and

 ploughed headlong in to drawing & painting.

It's interesting to see how my art is evolving.

 

IT IS TIME, THOUGH...TIME TO PULL IT OUT OF THE BAGS...

 QUIT TRYING TO SELL IT BY THE POUND!

   FRAME IT UP BEAUTIFULLY AND SHARE WITH THE PUBLIC...

 

'God paints the picture, I happen to hold the pen'....

With the encouragement of a dear friend, I got up the gumption to

write to the director of THE HERMITAGE FALL FEST

 ...and show him my work.

Quite frankly, I wasn't ready for his awesome response.

 I have to enter the show. People will want to see my art...

WOW....

 I got busy right away.

This is exactly the experience and exposure my work needs.

 It's my first show and I want it to be the best!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Fall Fest at The Hermitage is expecting 10,000 visitors

and art lovers from across the country.

Funding needed:

jury fee = $15 (paid)

booth space = $150 (due September 1st)

electricity = $25

Set up equipment (including 10x10 tent) = $200

Framing & Presentation of art = $650 (estimate)

ALL FUNDING RAISED WILL BE APPLIED

        TO ART SUPPLIES AND FUTURE SHOWS.

EVEN IF MY GOAL IS NOT REACHED, I'M GOING ANYWAY!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

FOR YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS:

 <$25  a small piece of original art

<$50   a larger piece of original art

>$100 a personalized piece of art work, original.

you tell me what you want and I'll design it...

 A NAME, A THEME, A FAVOURITE THING!

I am currently setting up an online gallery

where prints ~ large & small can be made of my work...

https://helenbird.virtualgallery.com/

 

and PLEASE, if you are unable to donate,

   share my project with your friends...

I have a feeling they'll love my art,

    there's much to look at

and something for everyone!

https://helenbird.virtualgallery.com/

      CHEERS!!!

    Helen Bird

story:
WHO WE ARE:

The F3B team believes that there are three things that can significantly improve a young person’s life.

  •  The opportunity to travel abroad.
  •  Defining a discipline.
  •  Gaining confidence in their communication skills.

So when we created our non-profit, F3B, almost 14 years ago, we kept those three factors at the forefront of our minds. For the last several years, we’ve cultivated a unique scholar athlete program — taking a small selection of the brightest female basketball players from high schools across the North East and giving them to opportunity to travel throughout Africa. Once there, they work, learn and practice their skills with young women in each country.

 

And our adventures have been a blast. Through F3B, the young women – many of them experiencing traveling abroad for the very first time – have traveled to more than 20 countries throughout Africa; including Ghana, Nigeria, South Africa, Ethiopia, Morocco, Liberia, Rwanda, Kenya, Botswana and Tanzania. In 2011, we even traveled to Romania and Bulgaria. In the last 14 years, we've met presidents, volunteered at orphanages and have organized more than 560 hours of basketball instruction combined for the African and American teens.

This summer the F3B team is traveling to Malawi, Tanzania and Zanzibar, but we need your help.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?:

So, you want to know how you can help make this experience even better for our teen girls?

This summer, the F3B team is scheduled to travel to Malawi, Tanzania and Zanzibar. From August 1st- August 17th, the teens will participate in a series of basketball and leadership development camps, while also exploring the culture and local people — including a visit to the U.S. embassy in Malawi, meeting with Joyce Banda, Malawi’s president, visiting several local orphanages in Tanzania and traveling by boat to Zanzibar. 

But we must raise more money for this year’s trip. Roughly $15,000.00 more.

  • The money will be used to subsidize this year's program for the 26 participating girls (six from America and 20 from Africa). Along with significantly subsidizing the program, it will also fund our visit to an orphanage where we will be donating clothing, books, crayons and toys.

Here's where YOU come in.

 

Through the years, we have had the opportunity to meet some of Africa’s top artists, who have continuously given their full support to our mission. We have also worked with emerging photographers, who have skillfully captured beautiful photographs of our programs abroad.

As part of our donation incentives, these artists have agreed to participate in our fundraiser by donating some of their best pieces at a fraction of their market value. We even have a special collaboration with artist, Frank Morrison, who has designed 30 limited edition F3B totes just for this campaign.

Trust us, we recognize how lucky we are for their support. And for the continuous support from people like you.

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

Follow us on Facebook!

Profiles on our Participating Artists:

+ Frank Morrison- One need take only a cursory view/examination of Frank's portfolio to find that his power and inspiration are products of his deeply religious grounding and his loving commitment to his family. Notable collections of Morrison’s art are owned by Queen Latifah,  "Earth Wind and Fire" Ralph Johnson,ED Gordan, and Bishop T.D. Jakes. His work has also enhanced the settings of televisions shows and movies "Just Right" , "Malcolm and Eddie", "New York Undercover", "Cosby" ,"The Rookie"  and has been a featured artist on the Home Shopping Network.

 

+ Ritah Edopu- Ritah Nabuyungo Edopu is perhaps better known for her penchant for bright colour, abstract monumental canvasses. Her interest among others includes discovering the new forms of technology that have embraced the fine arts industry. She specializes in making Paintings, (medium being oil, water, and acrylics), interior Design /Decoration and landscaping.

 

+ Lilian Nabulime- Lilian Nabulime is one of the few female sculptors in Uganda. She currently works on a combination of wood and sheet metal, producing monumental sculptures. Carving tree stumps has become her trademark. She selects the trunk searching for a motif from the stump. This she eventually teases out with her hammer and chisel, often making elongated, elegant sculptures, mainly women heads.

 

+ Mercy Moyo- Mercy Moyo has exhibited at the National Gallery of Art, Zimbabwe many times. In addition, her work has been included in shows in the Czech Republic, Finland, South Africa, and the United States. She is the first woman artist to win the National Arts Merit Award for two-dimensional work in Zimbabwe and has received a number of residencies. 

For more information about F3B and how you can help, visit our website at www.f3bscholars.org.

story:
The Artists
We are Josue and Wenceslao from the artists’ collective M.U.R.A.L. Project, based in Los Angeles.  M.U.R.A.L. Project focuses on community-based Art projects with at-risk youth and disenfranchised communities in Los Angeles and abroad. We collaborate with organizations and community members using Art as therapy, to beautify space, build community, and as an educational tool that reflects the people’s culture and life stories.

Our Goals
Our goals are to provide workshops and paint a mural in solidarity with community members at each refugee camp we visit in Palestine. In addition, we will work to bridge previous experiences working with diverse cultures in order to identify our common struggles and work to overcome those inequalities through art.

The Impact
The M.U.R.A.L. Project is honored to team up with Fellowship of Reconciliation Delegation of Artists from the U.S. and Asia to work with victims of war in Palestine and collaborate on multimedia projects for social change.  Working with Fellowship of Reconciliation will be a humbling experience that will allow us to learn from other non-violent movements for peace and justice that are happening in Palestine. By applying our newfound knowledge to future projects, these experiences will serve to enrich our continued work with disenfranchised communities.

Your Support
Since we are embarking on this journey without corporate sponsors or grants, we are asking for your financial support to fund this life-changing project and to continue our tireless work with war-torn communities in the Middle East. Your support will cover Airfare, Food and Lodging for Three Weeks.


Other ways you can help

  • Share this fundraiser’s Link with Everyone in your community.

  • Use Facebook, Twitter or Any social networking site to spread the word.


To learn more about Fellowship of Reconciliation and their past work around the world, please visit them at, www.forusa.org .

 

Limited Edition "El Mariachi" Giclée Print 18"x 24" - ( Blue Perk )

Sticker Design

story:
Our Story

HAND/EYE Magazine is a non-profit organization devoted to helping artists, artisans and designers all over the world gain exposure, find opportunities, and build their businesses.

The Impact

Our work has two different kinds of impact. First, our print and online work has resulted in new customers, collectors and collaborators for the creatives we profile. Second, at HAND/EYE, we believe that knowing each other on a cultural level creates a sense of unity and understanding. When we know and admire each other, the world is a warmer, better, more beautiful place.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $7,500 to send our photographer/videographer David A. Land and his sound man to South Africa to interview, film, and photograph many of the talented artists supported by Hand/Eye Fund. We will then take the resulting video, edit and distribute it in several formats, to be used to educate designers, wholesalers, buyers and consumers of the significance and cultural importance of preserving age-old crafting techniques along with their economic value to disadvantaged nations as a means for self-sufficiency.

 

Any money left over after our photojournalism need will go toward expenses incurred in layout, design, and article development for the July 2012 South Africa issue of Hand/Eye Magazine.

 

We have outlined several "perk" levels to inform and reward those who generously support us. We are using products from our previous project in Haiti, as well as rewards that we will create in South Africa.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to support financially, we still appreciate every tweet, every post and every action that increases awareness.  You can use the brilliant IndieGoGo Widget or just mention us in passing to friends who are interested in art, fashion, design and culture worldwide. 

 

*********************************************************

Fashion Accessory Give Away!

We're giving away a horn bangle/cuff from Haiti, made by the horn and bone guilde in Rue de la Reunion.  This piece of original Haitian design is a beautiful example of labor-intensive craft with high fashion appeal.  To be eligible, just forward this campaign to as many people you know, using the IndieGoGo tools above and help get us to our goal!

The process feels amazingly medieval; food biproduct such as horn is heated over a charcoal fire, then pressed by hand with a wheel press.  the flattened section of horn is then cut out by hand, fired and polished, then heated and rolled with a pipe, curled by hand to give the final shape.  The end product is both breathtaking and natural.

Help us achieve our goal, before the end of our campaign!  We will select at random, from those who forward on this project (we can track those who are logged into the IndieGoGo system), a winner of one these amazing bracelets.

story:
Berlin Unlimited is a project in and about Berlin based on the participation of the public: via an international open call we have invited submissions of work in a variety of media, coming from different disciplines, in order to create an interdisciplinary narrative of this (un)limited city. Exhibited in ZKU in October 2014, the jury-reviewed selection of the submissions, forms the basis of a programme of events bringing together artists, researchers, theorists, architects, urbanists, students and professionals, experts and the public. Our goal: an open multi-platform exchange of visions, ideas, and proposals about the city’s different realities, challenges and opportunities.

Berlin Unlimited: an exhibition, a talk series, a workshop, and parallel events, taking place in Berlin in October 2014.

Only twenty five years after the fall of the Berlin wall and the end of the “concrete division” (Willy Brandt, 10.09.1989), the city of Berlin is still in the process of re-definition and growth - a complex urban and political process, between the renewal of its own image as the “creative capital” and the establishing corporatism.

The exhibition “Berlin Unlimited” is aiming to explore the contradiction of urban realities - between matters of individual freedom and urban constraint. By means of art and creative media, architecture and urban design, theory and research, “Berlin Unlimited” aims to reveal an interdisciplinary narrative about the city and to display a critical view on its former limits, today’s limitations and tomorrow’s possible new divisions.

The exhibition will be accompanied by a series of public events: Discussions among invited professionals, artists, participants, and the public, will open up a broader dialogue around the opportunities and the challenges Berlin is currently facing. An unlimited programme of events such as film screenings, guided tours, intensive workshops, talks, creative caterings and unlimited parties will take place in ZK/U and around the city. 

Our aims, why we need your support and how we plan to use it: 

The project is made possible thanks to the voluntary work of an international network of collaborators passionate to:

1. Advance the work of artists, researchers, theorists, architects, urban design and planning professionals.

2. Promote an understanding of the city through the synergy of a multitude of disciplines and media.

3. Create new knowledge on the local particularities of the city of Berlin through a global spectrum of projects.

4. Promote public interest and debate about the city of Berlin and its urban development.

In the longer term, the project aims to:

1. Foster lasting collaborations and strong links among the exhibition’s participants, project partners and collaborators.

2. Contribute to the greater public agenda and debate on issues facing the contemporary city.

The whole team has been working hard and freely - without any limits! - to shape the ideal event program.

For you, we already gathered a team of highly qualified professionals willing to share their expertise and passion for Berlin with the public. The first stage of Berlin Unlimited has been launched in March 2014, through an open international call for ideas. 

The installation proposed through Berlin Unlimited in the space of the ZK/U is the opportunity of experimenting in a human scale a new kind of spatial disposals in order to create a political agora driving by cultural purposes.

We have the network, we have the experience, we have the perfect place… but to make it happen and to make it good, we need your support!

Thanks to you, we will be able to build up the perfect environment for the events, to invite foreign speakers to come and to maintain one of the main quality of the festival: to keep it free!

Sample of selected works:

Project selected - category Architecture: m3 / Valentin Cordebar, Camille Salomon

Project selected - category Arts (photography): Berlin / Christiane Wirth

Project selected - Category Architecture: The inverted type / Chien B. Wong

Project selected - Category Architecture: Low-tech tools and structures to actions of urban art / Narcelio Dantas

Who we are: The Berlin Unlimited Team

Urban Transcripts was born of a desire to create a new tool through which to explore the city as a complex phenomenon in a participatory and cross-disciplinary way. It was initiated in 2010 as an annual programme of events such as exhibitions, conferences, and workshops, focused on, and hosted in, a different city every year.

UT’s central mission is the advancement and production of work that betters the city, improves the built environment, enhances the quality of life in it, and furthers the understanding of the city as a complex phenomenon. We employ a synergy of disciplines and media to achieve it, as well as a corporate and working structure that advances a global-local network operation, bottom-up innovation, and public participation.

For Berlin Unlimited, Urban Transcripts paired up with CollageLab and Guerilla Architects, local-international urban researchers and (h)ac(k)tive architects, whose network, experience, expertise and motivation guarantee the high quality of the programme.

(from left to right: Stefanie Pesel, Joanne Pouzenc, Nike Kraft, Natalia Stepanova, Anja Fritz, Philine Schneider. + Yiorgos Papamanousakis, Nina Margies, Shahrzad Rahmani, Silvia Gioberti)

Berlin Unlimited, comes after similar programmes of events in Athens (2010), Rome (2011), and London (2012), as a continuation of UT’s commitment to its mission and its founding principles. 

Unlimited people: Guests and artists of the festival

UNLIMITED GUESTS
Jean-Philippe Vassal
Gabi Schillig
Anna Kostreva
Valeria Schwarz
Florian Hertweck
Philipp Oswalt
Daniel Fernandez Pascual
Alon Schwabe
Taina Guedes
Anna Galda
Thomas Kerekes
Karsten Michael Drohsel
Andy Graydon
Max Schwitalla
Jessica Bridger
Elvia Wilk
Pieterjan Grandry
Daniele Manchini
Catalina Pollak
Anne Köhler
Felipe Lanuza
Benedikt Stoll

story_txt:
Berlin Unlimited is a project in and about Berlin based on the participation of the public: via an international open call we have invited submissions of work in a variety of media, coming from different disciplines, in order to create an interdisciplinary narrative of this (un)limited city. Exhibited in ZKU in October 2014, the jury-reviewed selection of the submissions, forms the basis of a programme of events bringing together artists, researchers, theorists, architects, urbanists, students and professionals, experts and the public. Our goal: an open multi-platform exchange of visions, ideas, and proposals about the city’s different realities, challenges and opportunities.
Berlin Unlimited: an exhibition, a talk series, a workshop, and parallel events, taking place in Berlin in October 2014.
Only twenty five years after the fall of the Berlin wall and the end of the “concrete division” (Willy Brandt, 10.09.1989), the city of Berlin is still in the process of re-definition and growth - a complex urban and political process, between the renewal of its own image as the “creative capital” and the establishing corporatism.
The exhibition “Berlin Unlimited” is aiming to explore the contradiction of urban realities - between matters of individual freedom and urban constraint. By means of art and creative media, architecture and urban design, theory and research, “Berlin Unlimited” aims to reveal an interdisciplinary narrative about the city and to display a critical view on its former limits, today’s limitations and tomorrow’s possible new divisions.
The exhibition will be accompanied by a series of public events: Discussions among invited professionals, artists, participants, and the public, will open up a broader dialogue around the opportunities and the challenges Berlin is currently facing. An unlimited programme of events such as film screenings, guided tours, intensive workshops, talks, creative caterings and unlimited parties will take place in ZK/U and around the city. 
Our aims, why we need your support and how we plan to use it: 
The project is made possible thanks to the voluntary work of an international network of collaborators passionate to:
1. Advance the work of artists, researchers, theorists, architects, urban design and planning professionals.
2. Promote an understanding of the city through the synergy of a multitude of disciplines and media.
3. Create new knowledge on the local particularities of the city of Berlin through a global spectrum of projects.
4. Promote public interest and debate about the city of Berlin and its urban development.
In the longer term, the project aims to:
1. Foster lasting collaborations and strong links among the exhibition’s participants, project partners and collaborators.
2. Contribute to the greater public agenda and debate on issues facing the contemporary city.
The whole team has been working hard and freely - without any limits! - to shape the ideal event program.
For you, we already gathered a team of highly qualified professionals willing to share their expertise and passion for Berlin with the public. The first stage of Berlin Unlimited has been launched in March 2014, through an open international call for ideas. 
The installation proposed through Berlin Unlimited in the space of the ZK/U is the opportunity of experimenting in a human scale a new kind of spatial disposals in order to create a political agora driving by cultural purposes.
We have the network, we have the experience, we have the perfect place… but to make it happen and to make it good, we need your support!
Thanks to you, we will be able to build up the perfect environment for the events, to invite foreign speakers to come and to maintain one of the main quality of the festival: to keep it free!Sample of selected works:Project selected - category Architecture: m3 / Valentin Cordebar, Camille Salomon
Project selected - category Arts (photography): Berlin / Christiane WirthProject selected - Category Architecture: The inverted type / Chien B. Wong
Project selected - Category Architecture: Low-tech tools and structures to actions of urban art / Narcelio Dantas
Who we are: The Berlin Unlimited Team
Urban Transcripts was born of a desire to create a new tool through which to explore the city as a complex phenomenon in a participatory and cross-disciplinary way. It was initiated in 2010 as an annual programme of events such as exhibitions, conferences, and workshops, focused on, and hosted in, a different city every year.
UT’s central mission is the advancement and production of work that betters the city, improves the built environment, enhances the quality of life in it, and furthers the understanding of the city as a complex phenomenon. We employ a synergy of disciplines and media to achieve it, as well as a corporate and working structure that advances a global-local network operation, bottom-up innovation, and public participation.
For Berlin Unlimited, Urban Transcripts paired up with CollageLab and Guerilla Architects, local-international urban researchers and (h)ac(k)tive architects, whose network, experience, expertise and motivation guarantee the high quality of the programme.

(from left to right: Stefanie Pesel, Joanne Pouzenc, Nike Kraft, Natalia Stepanova, Anja Fritz, Philine Schneider. + Yiorgos Papamanousakis, Nina Margies, Shahrzad Rahmani, Silvia Gioberti)
Berlin Unlimited, comes after similar programmes of events in Athens (2010), Rome (2011), and London (2012), as a continuation of UT’s commitment to its mission and its founding principles.

story:
My name is Natskalla, ok I guess you realise that isn't my birth name but everyone has an alter-ego don't they ?

Natskalla is a nickname and when I started on my artistic journey I decided I wanted to have an alias, so it was only natural to use my nickname.


The reason I wanted an alias is that I wanted my art to be judged for exactly what it is which is about my passion for music and the ways it affects my artistic eye. Listening to music has always been a passion of mine for as long as I can remember, art came a very close second and when people started to comment on my drawings and noticed that every time I sketched a picture piano keys are featured in some shape or form, a friend suggested I should share my pictures, so that is what I did.  

I set up a facebook (facebook.com/natskalla) and then a facebook page (facebook.com/bynatskalla) and that is where my artistic journey began. The things you might want to know about me are that I am a 32 year old woman who is hard working, fun loving, determined, kind hearted, a dreamer, ambitious and creative.


Ok so enough about me .....lets get down to business :)
Im here to ask for your help to get Operation Good Karma off the ground.
My idea is to paint 100 10x8in canvases  of 5 different designs and randomly hand post them over the Birmingham area with a letter explaining what Operation Good Karma is about and asking them to get involved by taking a photo of the painting they have received and tagging it to either the facebook twitter or instagram for ByNatskalla, so in effect this is karma working at its best random people receiving a nice surprise and they keep the karma going by returning the good gesture.
The end idea is that I get free promotion for my work and people that may never have come across my work will see it and hopefully share it with a friend.

Here is a list of the things I will need that coincides with the amount I am trying to raise:
*150 10x8in canvas £ 2.00 each totalling £300.00 (one of these 5 designs)

 

*Acrylic paint set £19.99

*Watercolour Pencils £26.00
*Envelopes and paper for letters £3.00
*Postage £150.00 (for rewards)
*To cover processing fees £50

I hope you can see what I am I trying to achieve and the good karma I'm trying to create, check out my rewards  here's hoping they are an incentive for you to want to get involved too, 

Rewards - email postcards will be within 2 weeks of project ending and canvases will be within 5 weeks to ensure time to paint and post.

Thank you for your time xoxo

story:
Darger HQ just opened a 1300 sq ft. contemporary international art gallery and arts center in the heart of downtown Lincoln, NE.  It is the first of it’s kind in Lincoln!  People said it was crazy, and that the people of Nebraska are not interested in contemporary art.  I disagree.   Let’s create a positive change in the community and allow everyone the opportunity to participate in and be inspired by contemporary art.

Darger HQ is a non-profit gallery dedicated to presenting the work of emerging international, US and local artists and research practices that expand on theoretical approaches to contemporary art.  Every month Darger HQ will host exhibitions by top emerging US and international artists in the main gallery along side a local artist in the Local Artist Gallery. 

Outside the framework of the gallery program, Darger HQ will engage in educational outreach programs, community-based programs such as the downtown window installation initiative, host lectures, events, and organize contemporary art happenings in Lincoln.

Darger HQ aims to promote cross-cultural exchange by developing artistic projects that stimulate meaningful interaction between people.


How You Can Help

We just opened up our new space with our inaugural exhibition on June 6th.  You can help us keep the momentum going by making a contribution.  Funding will help us complete the remaining construction, off-set start-up costs and fund programming and events in our first year.  Make a contribution and get some sweet perks in return! 

We are raising $9750, which will be used as follows:

  • Complete lighting system (track lighting)
  • Newly surfaced walls / paint
  • Resurfacing of floors
  • Other minor construction costs
  • Furniture for community meeting space
  • Equipment (projector, flatscreen, speakers) for events, talks and screenings
  • Printing of exhibition and event marketing collateral material
  •  International and domestic shipping of artwork
  • Web design
  • Costs associated with community outreach (downtown window initiative, small town lectures, artist talks at UNL, performances)
  • Pay Interns

Perks

Get awesome perks from artist prints, VIP access to events and exhibitions, rental of space and sponsorship opportunities.  You can even sponsor a gallery space for a year!


About Darger HQ and Founder/Director Launa Bacon

Named after the posthumously famous, outsider American artist, Henry Darger, Darger HQ’s virtual gallery was founded in November 2012 has provided an influential platform for presenting important, emerging, international artists' work to new collectors.  Darger HQ is a grass-roots arts initiative run by artists, for artists. 

Launa Bacon has served as Director of Darger HQ since it’s inception in 2012.  She is an artist and educator and has been active in the international arts community for fifteen years.  Bacon received her BA from Skidmore College in 1997 and her MFA from Goldsmiths College in 2007.  Among others, Launa was the Director of London International Creative Competition (LICC) in London and a Director and Founder of Craftswoman House in Pasadena, California.  She presented enterprising projects by many successful artists exhibiting today.  Raised in Nebraska, (she had an art studio in the barn) Launa has recently returned and is excited to be a part of the local art community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
'INFINITE LONDON' 

'Infinite London' will be a fine art exhibition for emerging visual artists, who are based in London and create their art in London. It is planned to be an art event of the year! 

“London goes beyond any boundary or convention. It contains every wish or word ever spoken, every action or gesture ever made, every harsh or noble statement ever expressed. It is illimitable. It is infinite London.” Peter Ackroyd

‘Infinite London’ is inspired by London as a living, breathing, laughing, screaming entity in its own right, as perfectly captured by Peter Ackroyd in his book ‘London: The Biography’. We intend to match the animated nature of London with refined but vibrant entries from all of our selected artists. This does by no means only include pieces that depict our surroundings in a literal way. The works have to be made in London


DETAILS OF THE PROJECT:

• Location:  

The Vaults - Iconic Tunnels under Waterloo Underground Station, 5 minutes walk from Westminster (http://www.the-vaults.org)

•  Date:

15 - 19 October 2014 (during Frieze Art Fair, when the world’s art collectors and enthusiasts will be in London)

The exhibition will kick-off with an invitation-only opening night on 15 October, where guests will include partners, art collectors, politicians, journalists and bloggers. This will be followed by a public opening of four days for the general public and art enthusiasts  from 16 to 19 October.

•  Target Audience:  

LoVArts aims to attract 5,000 visitors to the exhibition, including Londoners, Art Collectors, Galleries, Curators, Journalists, Art Enthusiasts. Crucially, LoVArts will provide an event that is more accessible to also non-elite art enthusiasts than the Frieze Art Fair, by pricing tickets at £5 each (with concessions) in a non-traditional venue near one of London’s public transport hubs.

•  Mission:

The key mission of ‘Infinite London’ is to reveal talented, but still unknown artists who live and work in London, as well as to promote London as the world’s artistic hub.  All artworks must have been made in London by artists based in this city. 

• Accessible

Minimum costs for artists to submit and exhibit their artworks.

•  High Level of Artworks:

Artworks will be selected by a team of professional curators with cumulative experience across some of London’s most prestigious institutes, including:

- V&A

- British Museum

- Science Museum 

- Royal Academy of Arts.

We expect 1,000 submissions from which curators will choose the best 50 artists.

•  About the team:

We have a great team working every day to make sure this exhibition will be successful.


The other part of the team with additional 20+ people, includes (with sample clients):

Curators: Amelie von Harrach & Arturo Galansino (V&A, Royal Academy of Arts, National Gallery, Science Museum, British Museum)

Designer: Nova Collective (London Olympic Games, BBC, Disney Media, Ferrari, Shell)

Light Designer: Jonny Milmer Light Design (Land Rover, Canon, Battersea Power Station, Ford, BT Tower)

Video Producers: Stoke&Dagger (Barclays, Red Bull, Yahoo, Virgin Atlantic, National Geographic) 

Marketing & PR: TBurnsArts (Poetry Society, Blain Southern, Possitive View Foundation)

as well as art consultants, financial consultants, architects, marketing specialists, blog contributors and fundraising manager.




LONDON AS A HUMAN BODY:

Brief of 'Infinite London' for the Artists:

London is like a human body and I am one of its organs. We can’t live without each other, we can’t live separately. Humans are like little blood cells traveling through the artificial veins and arteries that are the streets and underground tunnels keeping the city alive and growing. I want to express my feelings and emotions towards this relationship through artwork. I act as the pulse of creativity that keeps the culture system flowing. I need to emphasise my importance in our coexistence.

As artists living in London, we are all in one way or another influenced by the city. It shapes our behaviour, our way of thinking, our everyday existence. It thus has an impact on the works of art we produce, whether the imagery and content are directly related to it or not. We are a part of London, and London is intrinsically connected to ourselves and our creative output.

There will be a selection of the best artworks depicting the emotions and inner feelings inspired by being part of London. LoVArts will encourage artists to ‘bare all’ in their artistic entries; we want refined but vibrant entries to be representative of the artists’ particular London experience, and how they wish to ‘give back’ creatively to the city’s atmosphere and life. 

A professional panel of curators (with cumulative experience across some of London’s most prestigious institutes, including V&A, the British Museum, the Science Museum and the Royal Academy of Arts) will choose the best artworks. 



FUTURE OF 'INFINITE LONDON'

'Infinite London' is planed to be the annual art event that takes place in London every October. We are also aiming at presenting the show abroad, including Dubai and New York. Each time the exhibition will be different, however, it will always expose artworks of the London based artists only. You can help us to make 'Infinite London' an event of the year!


ABOUT LOVARTS 

LoVArts - London Visual Arts is a non-profit organisation that functions as a promotional and networking platform for emerging visual artists based in London. 

We want to impact positively on the careers and aspirations of emerging artists through: regular networking meetings, seminars and promotional events curated by professionals. 

In terms of our public presence, we operate as a promotional and networking platform specifically designed to support emerging artists by promoting events that can help further their careers and aspirations. Through our regular networking meetings and seminars, every visual artist will have the right to voice their opinion and share their work in a friendly environment and will also have the opportunity to apply for our exhibitions, organised and curated by a team of professionals from the London art scene. Its purpose is simple, we hope to build a bridge between established artists represented by agents and galleries, and emerging artists by providing them with an alternative channel to show their work. Promotion through LoVArts will expose these artists to public feedback on a scale that they would otherwise not have access to.

The platform not only achieves exposure for the artists on the highest possible professional level but also serves as an introductory network so that reaching their target audience is facilitated. In essence, we discover ‘unknown artists’ and present them to the world in a format that will be recognisable to buyers, collectors and the wider art-savvy public. We firmly believe that the events that artists need are those which provide a channel to obtain commissions and sales.

More info: www.lovarts.co.uk 


WHAT WE NEED 

Our primary goal has been to raise 160 000 GBP. We already managed to raise 40 000 GBP in support in kind and we are looking to raise the rest of the funds through a few channels, including: crowdfunding, applying for art grants as well as private and corporate sponsorship.

We need your help to raise 40 000 GBP through IndieGoGo; your support will enable Infinite London to:

- Pay for the space at The Vault - We have yet to pay our deposit! We have  received amazing support from the Director of The Vaults, who loves the 'Infinite London' project. They have booked the venue for us, but we need to pay the venue fee as soon as possible. 

- Lighting - Our team includes a great Light Designer who will make 'Infinite London' even more spectacular. He has helped us to receive a 40% discount for all the lighting equipment rental! We need your help to raise funds for the equipment rental and installation.


Any funds raised in excess of 40,000 GBP (which would be fantastic!), will be allocated towards: 

  • Marketing
  • PR
  • Promotional Materials (posters, invitations, catalogues, badges) 
  • Sound - Yes, 'Infinite London' is the exhibition for visual artists, however, you will absorb the exhibition through all of your senses. To include sound, to stimulate all of your emotions, we need to rent sound equipment.
  • 'Infinite London' coffee book - Yes, we want to print a high quality book containing all the artwork in the exhibition
  • Transport & Packaging
  • Professional fees (accountants, lawyer)
  • Admin fees (insurance, registrations, portal hire)
  • Catering
  • Staff Costs - Although right now almost all of us work voluntarily, we still need to pay some people who will help us in tasks that we cannot take on
  • Other unexpected costs


WHAT YOU GET

We truly believe that your positive energy will come back to you, and we offer  every donator good karma :)

We also offer various goodies as moments of 'Infinite London' 

Most importantly, however, we offer two tickets to 'Infinite London' for everyone who supports us with at least 10 GBP! We would love to see all of our donators at the show in October! You are one of us!


THE IMPACT

We believe that 'Infinite London' will be a turning point in the artists' career. We have been working on this project since July 2013 and we feel that we are ready to give emerging artists significant exposure to the London art scene. It is also very important to remember that participation in 'Infinite London' has very low costs for artists. We want to make sure that we present the best artists, not only those who can afford to exhibit in the centre of London; this will all be  thanks to you!  


SPREAD THE WORD!

If you can't support us financially, don't worry! We would love you to spread the word about 'Infinite London'. Do not hesitate to contact us if you have any questions. We will answer them all as soon as we can. The more people who know about our campaign, the more successful it will be. We need your support in any and all forms. 

Here are few ways you can help 'Infinite London':

  • Click that "Share" button and post our campaign to your social media pages!
  • Send our campaign page to your friends using the email link!
  • Have a blog? Please consider mentioning us in a post!
  • Tweet about us! 

If you love this project, you can also support us in kind (helping with thousands of tasks we have to take on). If you would like to get involved give us a shout on info@lovarts.co.uk. 


Thank you!!!

We are looking forward to seeing you at 'Infinite London' in October!


#InfiniteLondon

Discover. Be Discovered.
